    name Tittle
    type string
    value Controlling Federated Learning for Covertness
  field 2
    name Authors
    type string
    value Adit Jain aj457@cornell.edu Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Cornell University Vikram Krishnamurthy vikramk@cornell.edu Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Cornell University 
  field 3
    name Abstract
    type string
    value 1 Introduction Contributions: This paper proposes a framework for the learner to dynamically query the oracle by solving a Markov decision process (MDP) to exploit the inherent stochasticity, making learning more robust and achieving covertness. Structural results are proven in TheoremÂ  2 and TheoremÂ  3 , which show that the optimal policy has a threshold structure (Fig.Â  1 (a)) which enables the use of efficient policy search methods. This framework can be extended to meta-learning problems like controlling learning for energy efficiency and quality control. A policy gradient algorithm which finds the optimal stationary policy solving the MDP controls the stochastic gradient descent as described by ( 1 ) and shown in Fig.Â  1 (b). The policy gradient algorithm is linear time due to the threshold nature of the optimal policy and does not need knowledge of the transition probabilities. The policy gradient algorithm runs on a faster time scale and can adapt to changes in the system. The methods are demonstrated on a novel application, covert federated learning (FL) on a text classification task using large language model embeddings. Our key numerical results are summarized in TableÂ  1 . It is shown that compared to a greedy policy when the learner is using the optimal policy, the optimal weights of that the eavesdroppers estimates do not generalize well, in both the scenarios discussed in detail laterÂ  1 1 1 A greedy policy poses learning queries until all the required successful updates are done to the model and then starts posing obfuscating queries. . This paper considers two practicalities: a stochastic oracle and an optimization queue. A stochastic oracle with different noise levels can model a non-i.i.d. client distribution in FL, and an optimization queue can model repeated optimization tasks like machine unlearning and distribution shifts. TheoremÂ  1 characterizes the number of successful updates required for convergence, and LemmaÂ  1 analyzes the stability of the queue. 2 Controlled Stochastic Gradient Descent for Covert Optimization For formulating the MDP in the next section, we need the following definition and theorem, which characterizes the finite nature of the optimization objective of ( 3 ). The proof of the theorem follows by applying the gradient lemma and standard convergence results to the update stepÂ  (Bottou, 2004 ; Ghadimi & Lan, 2013 ) and is given in the Appendix. Successful Update : At time k k k an iteration of ( 4 ) is a successful update if ğŸ™ â€‹ ( Ïƒ k 2 â‰¤ Ïƒ 2 ) â€‹ ğŸ™ â€‹ ( u k = 1 ) = 1 1 superscript subscript Ïƒ k 2 superscript Ïƒ 2 1 subscript u k 1 1 \\mathbbm{1}\\left(\\sigma_{k}^{2}\\leq\\sigma^{2}\\right)\\mathbbm{1}\\left(u_{k}=1\\right)=1 . ( Required number of successful updates ) Learner â„’ â„’ \\mathcal{L} querying an oracle ğ’ª ğ’ª \\mathcal{O} which satisfies assumptions (A1-2) using a controlled stochastic gradient descentÂ  7 7 7 The SGD analysis can be extended to algorithms with faster convergence like momentum based AdamÂ  ( Kingma & Ba , 2017 ) as is illustrated in the numerical studies. Besides simplicity, SGD is shown to have better generalizability Â  Zhou etÂ al. ( 2020 ) ; Wilson etÂ al. ( 2017 ) . with updates of the form ( 4 ), needs to perform M ğ‘€ M successful updates (Def. 1 ) to get Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon -close to a critical point ( 3 ), where M = O â€‹ ( exp â¡ ( L â€‹ Ïƒ 2 Ïµ ) ) . ğ‘€ ğ‘‚ ğ¿ superscript ğœ 2 italic-Ïµ \\displaystyle M=O\\left(\\exp\\left(\\frac{L\\sigma^{2}}{\\epsilon}\\right)\\right). Given an equal prior over disjoint intervals, an eavesdropper using a proportional sampling estimator calculates the posterior probability of the minima lying in an interval proportional to the number of queries observed in the interval. Since this work considers two disjoint SGD trajectories, the eavesdropperâ€™s posterior probability of the minima belonging to one of the SGD trajectories given equal priors is proportional to the number of queries in the trajectories, Proportional sampling estimator : If the eavesdropper (with assumptions E1-2) observes queries belonging to two SGD trajectory sequences I I I and J J J and has equal prior over both of them, then the eavesdropperâ€™s posterior belief of the learnerâ€™s true estimate x ^ ^ x \\hat{x} belonging to I I I is given by, P I â€‹ = Î” â€‹ â„™ â€‹ ( x ^ âˆˆ I | ( q 1 , q 2 , â€¦ , q N ) ) = | I | | I | + | J | subscript P I Î” â„™ ^ x conditional I subscript q 1 subscript q 2 â€¦ subscript q N I I J P_{I}\\overset{\\Delta}{=}\\mathbb{P}(\\hat{x}\\in I|(q_{1},q_{2},\\dots,q_{N}))=\\frac{|I|}{|I|+|J|} . 3 Controlling the Stochastic Gradient Descent using a Markov decision process (Queue stability) Let the smallest success probability be g min = min y O âˆˆ ğ’® O â¡ g â€‹ ( u = 1 , y O ) subscript g subscript superscript y O subscript ğ’® O g u 1 superscript y O g_{\\min}=\\min_{y^{O}\\in\\mathcal{S}_{O}}g(u=1,y^{O}) . If, Î´ â€‹ M g min < 1 âˆ’ Î› l â€‹ ( 0 , W ) , ğ›¿ ğ‘€ subscript ğ‘” 1 Î› ğ‘™ 0 ğ‘Š \\displaystyle\\frac{\\delta M}{g_{\\min}}<1-\\frac{\\Lambda}{l(0,W)}, then every policy satisfying the constraint in ( 9 ) induces a stable queue and a recurrent Markov chain. This subsection proves structural results for the optimal policy solving the MDP and the CMDP. The threshold structure of the optimal policy substantially reduces the search space and is used in devising the structured policy gradient algorithm. The following theorem proves that the optimal policy, Î½ âˆ— superscript ğœˆ \\nu^{*} solving the finite horizon MDP of ( 7 ) has a threshold structure with respect to the learner state, y n L subscript superscript ğ‘¦ ğ¿ ğ‘› y^{L}_{n} . (Nature of optimal policy Î½ âˆ— superscript Î½ \\nu^{*} ) The optimal policy solving the finite horizon MDP of ( 7 ) with assumptions ( M1-3 ) is deterministic and monotonically increasing in the learner state, y L superscript y L y^{L} . (Existence of randomized stationary policy) Â  (Sennott, 1993 ) There exists an optimal stationary policy solving the CMDP of ( 9 ), which is a randomized mixture of optimal policies of two average Lagrangian cost MDPs, Î½ âˆ— = p â€‹ Î½ Î» 1 âˆ— + ( 1 âˆ’ p ) â€‹ Î½ Î» 2 âˆ— , superscript ğœˆ ğ‘ subscript superscript ğœˆ subscript ğœ† 1 1 ğ‘ subscript superscript ğœˆ subscript ğœ† 2 \\displaystyle\\nu^{*}=p\\nu^{*}_{\\lambda_{1}}+(1-p)\\nu^{*}_{\\lambda_{2}}, (12) where Î½ Î» 1 âˆ— subscript superscript ğœˆ subscript ğœ† 1 \\nu^{*}_{\\lambda_{1}} and Î½ Î» 2 âˆ— subscript superscript ğœˆ subscript ğœ† 2 \\nu^{*}_{\\lambda_{2}} are optimal policies for average Lagrangian cost MDPs of the form ( 10 ). Our policy gradient algorithm updates the parameter estimates Î˜ n subscript Î˜ ğ‘› \\Theta_{n} using ( 15 ) by taking an approximate gradient of the average costs, the constraint in ( 9 ) and Î¾ n subscript ğœ‰ ğ‘› \\xi_{n} which updates using ( 15 ). The parameters which are updated are chosen randomly using a vector Î“ Î“ \\Gamma , the components of which have an i.i.d. Bernoulli distribution. These chosen parameters are perturbed by + Ï‰ ğœ” +\\omega and âˆ’ Ï‰ ğœ” -\\omega and the approximate gradient of the privacy and learning cost is denoted by Î” â€‹ c Î” ğ‘ \\Delta c and Î” â€‹ l Î” ğ‘™ \\Delta l , respectively. The approximate gradients of these costs are computed using a finite difference method on the approximate costs. The approximate average costs are computed by interacting with the Markovian oracle for T ğ‘‡ T timesteps. The approximate average learning cost is denoted by l ^ ^ ğ‘™ \\hat{l} . Îº ğœ… \\kappa and Ï ğœŒ \\rho are suitably chosen step and scale parametersÂ  15 15 15 The step size is constant if we want the SPGA to track change in the underlying system without convergence guarantees and decreasing otherwise. . Î˜ n + 1 = Î˜ n âˆ’ Îº â€‹ ( Î” â€‹ c + Î” â€‹ l Ã— max â¡ [ 0 , Î¾ n + Ï â€‹ ( l ^ âˆ’ Î› ) ] ) Î¾ n + 1 = max â¡ [ ( 1 âˆ’ Îº Ï â€‹ Î¾ n ) , Î¾ n + Îº â€‹ ( l ^ âˆ’ Î› ) ] subscript Î˜ ğ‘› 1 subscript Î˜ ğ‘› ğœ… Î” ğ‘ Î” ğ‘™ 0 subscript ğœ‰ ğ‘› ğœŒ ^ ğ‘™ Î› subscript ğœ‰ ğ‘› 1 1 ğœ… ğœŒ subscript ğœ‰ ğ‘› subscript ğœ‰ ğ‘› ğœ… ^ ğ‘™ Î› \\displaystyle\\begin{split}\\Theta_{n+1}=\\Theta_{n}-\\kappa\\left(\\Delta c+\\Delta l\\times\\max\\left[0,\\xi_{n}+\\rho\\left(\\hat{l}-\\Lambda\\right)\\right]\\right)\\\\ \\xi_{n+1}=\\max\\left[\\left(1-\\frac{\\kappa}{\\rho}\\xi_{n}\\right),\\xi_{n}+\\kappa\\left(\\hat{l}-\\Lambda\\right)\\right]\\end{split} (15) The SPGA algorithm can run on a faster time scale by interacting with the system parallel to the SGD and updating the stationary policy parameters, Î˜ Î˜ \\Theta . The stationary policy controls the query posed and updates the SGD estimate in ( 1 ). The computational complexity for the SPGA algorithm described here is O â€‹ ( | ğ’® | ) ğ‘‚ ğ’® O(|\\mathcal{S}|) , i.e., the algorithm is linear in the state space and hence significantly more scalable than standard policy gradient methodsÂ  (Kushner & Yin, 2003 ) . 4 Hate speech classification in a federated setting 5 Conclusion The problem of covert optimization is studied from a dynamic perspective when the oracle is stochastic, and the learner receives new optimization requests. The problem is modeled as a Markov decision process, and structural results are established for the optimal policy. A linear time policy gradient algorithm is proposed, and the application of our framework is demonstrated in a hate speech classification context. Future work can look at inverse RL techniques for the eavesdropper to infer the optimal learner policy, and more robust gradient trajectory hiding schemes can be studied. The problem of covert optimization can be investigated in a decentralized setting where the problem is modeled as a switching control game with participants switching between learning and obfuscating others. Our suggested methodology can dynamically control learning in distributed settings for objectives like energy efficiency, client privacy, and client selection. An eavesdropper with finite memory and an objective of minimizing average learning cost with a constraint on average privacy cost can be considered. This workâ€™s main broader ethical concerns are a) an increase in energy consumption to achieve covertness and b) it could help a learner covertly train a classifier for questionable reasons, e.g., censorship.
  field 4
    name Content
    type string
    value Abstract A learner aims to minimize a function f ğ‘“ f by repeatedly querying a distributed oracle that provides noisy gradient evaluations. At the same time, the learner seeks to hide arg â¡ min â¡ f ğ‘“ \\arg\\min f from a malicious eavesdropper that observes the learnerâ€™s queries. This paper considers the problem of covert or learner-private optimization, where the learner has to dynamically choose between learning and obfuscation by exploiting the stochasticity. The problem of controlling the stochastic gradient algorithm for covert optimization is modeled as a Markov decision process, and we show that the dynamic programming operator has a supermodular structure implying that the optimal policy has a monotone threshold structure. A computationally efficient policy gradient algorithm is proposed to search for the optimal querying policy without knowledge of the transition probabilities. As a practical application, our methods are demonstrated on a hate speech classification task in a federated setting where an eavesdropper can use the optimal weights to generate toxic content, which is more easily misclassified. Numerical results show that when the learner uses the optimal policy, an eavesdropper can only achieve a validation accuracy of 52 % percent 52 52\\% with no information and 69 % percent 69 69\\% when it has a public dataset with 10% positive samples compared to 83 % percent 83 83\\% when the learner employs a greedy policy. 
doc 5
  field 0
    name NameDoc
    type string
    value 2310.02554.html
  field 1
    name Tittle
    type string
    value zkFL : Zero-Knowledge Proof-based Gradient Aggregation for Federated Learning
  field 2
    name Authors
    type string
    value Zhipeng Wang Nanqing Dong Jiahao Sun William Knottenbelt 
  field 3
    name Abstract
    type string
    value 1 Introduction Federated Learning (FL) is a privacy-preserving machine learning paradigm that allows multiple clients to collaboratively train a global model without sharing their raw dataÂ  [ 23 ] . In FL, each participant ( i.e. , client) performs local training on its own private dataset and communicates only the model updates to the central server ( i.e. , aggregator). The aggregator aggregates the model updates and sends the updated global model back to the clients. This process repeats iteratively until the global model converges or a stopping criterion is fulfilled. During the cross-device \\ac FL process, participants need to place their trust in the aggregator to create cohorts of clients in a fair and unbiased manner. However, a potential vulnerability is that an actively malicious adversary with control over the aggregator could exploit this trustÂ  [ 17 ] . For instance, adversaries could carry out a Sybil attackÂ  [ 7 ] by simulating numerous fake client devices, and the adversary could also selectively favor previously compromised clientsâ€™ model updates from the pool of available participants. These attacks have the potential to enable the adversary to manipulate the final training results in \\ac FL, compromising the integrity of the learning process. Safeguarding against such threats is imperative to maintain the effectiveness and security of cross-device \\ac FL. In this work, we present zkFL ( cf. Â Fig.Â  1 ), an innovative approach that integrates zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) into FL. Without changing the learning setup of the underlying FL method, this integration guarantees the integrity of aggregated data from the centralized aggregator. \\acp ZKPÂ  [ 12 , 28 , 6 , 22 ] are widely recognized cryptographic tools that enable secure and private computations while safeguarding the underlying data. In essence, ZKPs empower a prover to convince a verifier of a specific fact without revealing any information beyond that fact itself. Within the context of zkFL , ZKPs play a pivotal role in addressing the challenge posed by a potentially malicious aggregator during the model aggregation process. To achieve accurate aggregation results, the aggregator must provide a proof for each round, demonstrating to the clients that it has faithfully executed the intended behavior for aggregating the model updates. By verifying these proofs, the clients can ensure the aggregatorâ€™s actions are transparent and verifiable, instilling confidence that the aggregation process is conducted with utmost honesty. Furthermore, in order to minimize the verification burden on the clients, we propose a blockchain-based zkFL solution to handle the proof in a zero-knowledge manner. As shown in Fig.Â  2 , in this approach, the blockchain acts as a decentralized and trustless platform, allowing miners , the nodes validating and maintaining the blockchain dataÂ  [ 25 , 4 ] , to verify the authenticity of the \\ac ZKP proof without compromising the confidentiality of the clientsâ€™ models. By incorporating blockchain technology into our zkFL system, we establish a robust and scalable framework for conducting zero-knowledge proof verification in a decentralized and transparent manner. This not only enhances the overall efficiency of the zkFL system but also reinforces the confidentiality of the participantsâ€™ data, making it a promising solution for secure and privacy-conscious cross-device \\ac FL. Our contributions can be summarized as follows: â€¢ We present zkFL , an innovative \\ac ZKP-based \\ac FL system that can be integrated with existing FL methods. zkFL empowers clients to independently verify proofs generated by the centralized aggregator, thereby ensuring the accuracy and validity of model aggregation results. zkFL effectively addresses the threats posed by the malicious aggregators during the training model aggregation process, enhancing security and trust in the collaborative \\ac FL setting. â€¢ We integrate zkFL with blockchain technology to minimize clientsâ€™ computation costs for verification. Leveraging the zero-knowledge property of \\acp ZKP, our blockchain-based zkFL significantly improves overall efficiency while preserving clientsâ€™ model privacy. â€¢ We present rigorous theoretical analysis on the security, privacy, and efficiency of zkFL . We further evaluate these properties under benchmark \\ac FL setups. The results of these experiments demonstrate the practical feasibility and effectiveness of zkFL in real-world scenarios. 2 Related Work 3 Preliminaries In this section, we present the cryptographic building blocks for our zkFL system. A commitment scheme enables an entity to conceal a value while committing to it, with the ability to disclose the value at a later time if desired. The commitment scheme typically comprises two rounds: the committing round and the revealing round. In the committing round, the client commits to specific values while ensuring their confidentiality from others. The client retains the option to reveal the committed value in the subsequent revealing round. A commitment scheme includes two algorithms: â€¢ ğ–¼ğ—† â† Commit â€‹ ( m , r ) â† ğ–¼ğ—† Commit ğ‘š ğ‘Ÿ \\mathsf{cm}\\leftarrow\\textsc{Commit}(m,r) accepts a message m ğ‘š m and a secret randomness r ğ‘Ÿ r as inputs and returns the commitment ğ–¼ğ—† ğ–¼ğ—† \\mathsf{cm} . â€¢ 0 / 1 â† Verify â€‹ ( m , r , ğ–¼ğ—† ) â† 0 1 Verify ğ‘š ğ‘Ÿ ğ–¼ğ—† 0/1\\leftarrow\\textsc{Verify}(m,r,\\mathsf{cm}) accepts a message m ğ‘š m , a commitment ğ–¼ğ—† ğ–¼ğ—† \\mathsf{cm} and a decommitment value r ğ‘Ÿ r as inputs, and returns 1 1 1 if the commitment is opened correctly and 0 0 otherwise. In this paper, we leverage Pedersen commitmentsÂ  [ 26 , 1 ] to compute the clientsâ€™ commitments/encryption on their local training model updates. Specifically, given the model update w i subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– w_{i} , a client will encrypt the update by computing E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) = g w i â‹… h s i ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– â‹… superscript ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– superscript â„ subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– Enc(w_{i})=g^{w_{i}}\\cdot h^{s_{i}} , where g ğ‘” g and h â„ h are public parameters and s i subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– s_{i} is a random number generated by the client. Zero-knowledge proofÂ  [ 18 , 11 , 29 ] is a cryptographic primitive that allows a prover to convince the verifier about the correctness of some assertions without providing any meaningful information to the verifier. A zero-knowledge proof of some statement satisfies the following three properties: â€¢ Completeness: If the statement st is true, an honest verifier will always be convinced by an honest prover. â€¢ Soundness: For false statements, a prover cannot convince the verifier (even if the prover cheats and deviates from the protocol). â€¢ Zero-knowledge: No verifier learns anything other than the fact that st is valid if it is true. In other words, knowing the statement, but not the secret, is enough to construct a scenario in which the prover knows the secret. A zero-knowledge Succinct Non-interactive ARgument of Knowledge (zk-SNARK) is a â€œsuccinctâ€ non-interactive zero-knowledge proof (NIZK) for arithmetic circuit satisfiability. The construction of zk-SNARK is based on a field ğ”½ ğ”½ \\mathbb{F} and an arithmetic circuit C ğ¶ C . An arithmetic circuit satisfiability problem of a circuit C : ğ”½ n Ã— ğ”½ h â†’ ğ”½ l : ğ¶ â†’ superscript ğ”½ ğ‘› superscript ğ”½ â„ superscript ğ”½ ğ‘™ C:\\mathbb{F}^{n}\\times\\mathbb{F}^{h}\\rightarrow\\mathbb{F}^{l} is captured by the statement st C : { ( x , ğ—ğ—‚ğ— ) âˆˆ ğ”½ n Ã— ğ”½ h : C â€‹ ( x , ğ—ğ—‚ğ— ) = 0 l } : subscript st ğ¶ conditional-set ğ‘¥ ğ—ğ—‚ğ— superscript ğ”½ ğ‘› superscript ğ”½ â„ ğ¶ ğ‘¥ ğ—ğ—‚ğ— superscript 0 ğ‘™ \\textit{st}_{C}:\\{(x,{\\mathsf{wit}})\\in\\mathbb{F}^{n}\\times\\mathbb{F}^{h}:C(x,\\mathsf{wit})=0^{l}\\} , with the language â„’ C = { x âˆˆ ğ”½ n | âˆƒ ğ—ğ—‚ğ— âˆˆ ğ”½ h â€‹ s . t . C â€‹ ( x , ğ—ğ—‚ğ— ) = 0 l } subscript â„’ ğ¶ conditional-set ğ‘¥ superscript ğ”½ ğ‘› formulae-sequence ğ—ğ—‚ğ— superscript ğ”½ â„ ğ‘  ğ‘¡ ğ¶ ğ‘¥ ğ—ğ—‚ğ— superscript 0 ğ‘™ \\mathcal{L}_{C}=\\{x\\in\\mathbb{F}^{n}~{}|~{}\\exists~{}\\mathsf{wit}\\in\\mathbb{F}^{h}~{}s.t.~{}C(x,\\mathsf{wit})=0^{l}\\} . Apart from correctness, soundness, and zero-knowledge properties of zero-knowledge proof, a zk-SNARK requires two additional properties, i.e. , succinctness and simulation extractability Â  [ 12 , 2 ] . 4 System and Threat Models In this section, we outline our system model, threat model, and system goals. â€¢ Clients : In the context of \\ac FL, clients represent individual devices, such as smartphones, tablets, or computers, each possessing its local dataset. These datasets remain secure and never leave the clientsâ€™ devices. Instead, the clients independently train their machine learning models on their local data and communicate only the model updates to the central aggregator. â€¢ Aggregator : The aggregator acts as a central entity responsible for aggregating these model updates from multiple clients and computing a global model. This global model is then sent back to the clients, ensuring that each client benefits from the collective knowledge of the entire network while preserving data privacy and security. We consider a malicious aggregator that can choose not to honestly aggregate the local model updates from clients. The malicious aggregator can deviate from the protocol by: â€¢ Abandoning the updates generated from one or several honest clients. â€¢ Creating fake model updates to replace the updates generated from honest clients, â€¢ Inserting fake model updates to the updates generated from honest clients. We would like to remark that the scope of this work centers around the malicious aggregator rather than the honest-but-curious one, with a specific emphasis on ensuring aggregation integrity. We also acknowledge the potential for the aggregator to carry out model inversion attacks on the clients, a topic we intend to delve into in a future study. â€¢ Security : The aggregator cannot abandon or replace the local model updates generated from honest clients, nor insert any fake model updates into the final aggregated model update. Otherwise, the clients will detect the malicious behaviors of the aggregator and halt the \\ac FL training process. â€¢ Privacy : Only the participants ( i.e. , the aggregator and clients) in the \\ac FL system can know the aggregated model updates during each round. 5 Methodology As shown in Fig.Â  1 , our zkFL system works as follows: 1. Setup: N ğ‘ N clients and 1 1 1 aggregator generate their private/public key pairs and set up communication channels. Each client knows the public keys of the other n âˆ’ 1 ğ‘› 1 n-1 clients, and this setup can be achieved by using a public key infrastructure (PKI). 2. Local Training, Encrypting, and Signing: During each round, the n ğ‘› n clients train their models locally to compute the local model updates w 1 , w 2 , â€¦ , w n subscript ğ‘¤ 1 subscript ğ‘¤ 2 â€¦ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘› w_{1},w_{2},â€¦,w_{n} . Each client encrypts their update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) = g w i â‹… h s i ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– â‹… superscript ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– superscript â„ subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– Enc(w_{i})=g^{w_{i}}\\cdot h^{s_{i}} using Pedersen commitment, where g ğ‘” g and h â„ h are public parameters and s i subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– s_{i} is a random number generated by the client. The client signs the encrypted updates with their private key to generate a signature s â€‹ i â€‹ g i ğ‘  ğ‘– subscript ğ‘” ğ‘– sig_{i} . The client then sends the tuple of local model update, the randomly generated number, encrypted local model update, and signature ( w i , s i , E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) , s â€‹ i â€‹ g i ) subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ğ‘  ğ‘– subscript ğ‘” ğ‘– (w_{i},s_{i},Enc(w_{i}),sig_{i}) to the aggregator. 3. Global Aggregation and \\ac ZKP Generation: The aggregator aggregates the received local model updates w 1 , w 2 , â€¦ , w n subscript ğ‘¤ 1 subscript ğ‘¤ 2 â€¦ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘› w_{1},w_{2},â€¦,w_{n} to generate the aggregated global model update w = âˆ‘ i = 1 n w i ğ‘¤ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– w=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}{w_{i}} . The aggregator then leverages zk-SNARK to issue a proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi for the following statement and witness: { s t a t e m e n t = ( E n c ( w 1 ) , s i g 1 , E n c ( w 2 ) , s i g 2 , â€¦ , E n c ( w n ) , s i g n , E n c ( w ) ) w â€‹ i â€‹ t â€‹ n â€‹ e â€‹ s â€‹ s = ( w 1 , s 1 , w 2 , s 2 , â€¦ , w n , s n , w ) \\begin{cases}&\\text{$statement=(Enc(w_{1}),sig_{1},Enc(w_{2}),sig_{2},$}\\\\ &~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\\text{$...,Enc(w_{n}),sig_{n},Enc(w))$}\\\\ &\\text{$witness=(w_{1},s_{1},w_{2},s_{2},...,w_{n},s_{n},w)$}\\end{cases} where the corresponding circuit C â€‹ ( s â€‹ t â€‹ a â€‹ t â€‹ e â€‹ m â€‹ e â€‹ n â€‹ t , w â€‹ i â€‹ t â€‹ n â€‹ e â€‹ s â€‹ s ) ğ¶ ğ‘  ğ‘¡ ğ‘ ğ‘¡ ğ‘’ ğ‘š ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ğ‘¡ ğ‘› ğ‘’ ğ‘  ğ‘  C(statement,witness) outputs 0 0 if and only if: { (i) âˆ€ 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n , E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) = g w i â‹… h s i (ii) w = âˆ‘ i = 1 n w i (iii) s â€‹ i â€‹ g i Â is signed by the clientÂ  i cases (i) formulae-sequence for-all 1 ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– â‹… superscript ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– superscript â„ subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– (ii) ğ‘¤ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– (iii) s i g i Â is signed by the clientÂ  i \\begin{cases}$(i)$&\\text{$\\forall 1\\leq i\\leq n,Enc(w_{i})=g^{w_{i}}\\cdot h^{s_{i}}$}\\\\ $(ii)$&\\text{$w=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}{w_{i}}$}\\\\ $(iii)$&\\text{$sig_{i}$ is signed by the client $i$}\\end{cases} (1) 4. Global Model Transmission and Proof Broadcast: The aggregator transfers the aggregated global model update w ğ‘¤ w , its encryption E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) and the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi to the n ğ‘› n clients. 5. Verification: Upon receiving the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi and the encrypted global model update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) from the aggregator, the clients verify if Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi is valid. When the verification is passed, the clients start their local training based on the aggregated global model update w ğ‘¤ w . To decrease the computation burden on clients, we incorporate blockchain technology into our zkFL system. In this approach, the verification of proofs generated by the aggregator is entrusted to blockchain miners . Illustrated in FigureÂ  2 , the blockchain-based zkFL operates as follows: 1. Setup: N ğ‘ N clients and 1 1 1 aggregator generate their private/public key pairs, which correspond to their on-chain addresses. 2. Selection: For each round, n ğ‘› n clients are selected from the N ğ‘ N clients via Verifiable Random FunctionsÂ  [ 24 , 3 ] . The n ğ‘› n selected clientsâ€™ public keys are broadcasted to the underlying P2P network of the blockchain, which will be received and verified by the miners. 3. Local Training, Encrypting, and Signing: The n ğ‘› n selected clients train their models locally to compute the local model updates w 1 , w 2 , â€¦ , w n subscript ğ‘¤ 1 subscript ğ‘¤ 2 â€¦ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘› w_{1},w_{2},â€¦,w_{n} . Each client encrypts their update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) = g w i â‹… h s i ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– â‹… superscript ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– superscript â„ subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– Enc(w_{i})=g^{w_{i}}\\cdot h^{s_{i}} using Pedersen commitment, where g ğ‘” g and h â„ h are public parameters and s i subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– s_{i} is a random number generated by the client. The client signs the encrypted updates with their private key to generate a signature s â€‹ i â€‹ g i ğ‘  ğ‘– subscript ğ‘” ğ‘– sig_{i} . The client then sends the tuple of local model update, the randomly generated number, encrypted local model update, and signature ( w i , s i , E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) , s â€‹ i â€‹ g i ) subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ğ‘  ğ‘– subscript ğ‘” ğ‘– (w_{i},s_{i},Enc(w_{i}),sig_{i}) to the aggregator. 4. Global Aggregation and \\ac ZKP Generation: The aggregator aggregates the received local model updates w 1 , w 2 , â€¦ , w n subscript ğ‘¤ 1 subscript ğ‘¤ 2 â€¦ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘› w_{1},w_{2},â€¦,w_{n} to generate the aggregated global model update w = âˆ‘ i = 1 n w i ğ‘¤ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– w=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}{w_{i}} . The aggregator also computes the aggregated value of the encrypted global model update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) = âˆ i = 1 n E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ superscript subscript product ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– Enc(w)=\\prod_{i=1}^{n}Enc(w_{i}) and signs it with its private key to generate the signature s â€‹ i â€‹ g ğ‘  ğ‘– ğ‘” sig . The aggregator then leverages zk-SNARK to issue a proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi for the following statement and witness: { s t a t e m e n t = ( E n c ( w 1 ) , s i g 1 , E n c ( w 2 ) , s i g 2 , â€¦ , E n c ( w n ) , s i g n , E n c ( w ) ) w â€‹ i â€‹ t â€‹ n â€‹ e â€‹ s â€‹ s = ( w 1 , s 1 , w 2 , s 2 , â€¦ , w n , s n , w ) \\begin{cases}&\\text{$statement=(Enc(w_{1}),sig_{1},Enc(w_{2}),sig_{2},$}\\\\ &~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\\text{$...,Enc(w_{n}),sig_{n},Enc(w))$}\\\\ &\\text{$witness=(w_{1},s_{1},w_{2},s_{2},...,w_{n},s_{n},w)$}\\end{cases} where the corresponding circuit C â€‹ ( s â€‹ t â€‹ a â€‹ t â€‹ e â€‹ m â€‹ e â€‹ n â€‹ t , w â€‹ i â€‹ t â€‹ n â€‹ e â€‹ s â€‹ s ) ğ¶ ğ‘  ğ‘¡ ğ‘ ğ‘¡ ğ‘’ ğ‘š ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ğ‘¡ ğ‘› ğ‘’ ğ‘  ğ‘  C(statement,witness) outputs 0 0 if and only if: { (i) âˆ€ 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n , E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) = g w i â‹… h s i (ii) w = âˆ‘ i = 1 n w i (iii) s â€‹ i â€‹ g i Â is signed by the clientÂ  i cases (i) formulae-sequence for-all 1 ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– â‹… superscript ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– superscript â„ subscript ğ‘  ğ‘– (ii) ğ‘¤ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– (iii) s i g i Â is signed by the clientÂ  i \\begin{cases}$(i)$&\\text{$\\forall 1\\leq i\\leq n,Enc(w_{i})=g^{w_{i}}\\cdot h^{s_{i}}$}\\\\ $(ii)$&\\text{$w=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}{w_{i}}$}\\\\ $(iii)$&\\text{$sig_{i}$ is signed by the client $i$}\\end{cases} 5. Global Model Transmission and Proof Broadcast: The aggregator transfers the aggregated global model update w ğ‘¤ w and its encryption E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) to the n ğ‘› n clients, and broadcasts the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi , and the encrypted global model update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) to the miners over the P2P network. 6. On-Chain Verification: Upon receiving the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi and the encrypted global model update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) from the aggregator, the miners verify Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi and append E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) to the blockchain if Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi is valid. 7. On-Chain Reading: When the next round starts, the newly selected n ğ‘› n clients read the blockchain to check if E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) is appended on-chain. When the check is valid, the clients start their local training based on the aggregated global model update w ğ‘¤ w . 6 Theoretical Analysis In the following, we provide analyses to show that our zkFL and blockchain-based zkFL systems can achieve the goals of security and privacy, while merely bringing an acceptable decrease in the FL training efficiency. Our zkFL and blockchain-based zkFL can achieve the security goal through the following techniques: â€¢ The signatures s â€‹ i â€‹ g i ğ‘  ğ‘– subscript ğ‘” ğ‘– sig_{i} of each encrypted local update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– Enc(w_{i}) ensure the local updatesâ€™ integrity from the clients and prevent the aggregator from tampering with their content and the statement s t a t e m e n t = ( E n c ( w 1 ) , s i g 1 , â€¦ , E n c ( w n ) , statement=(Enc(w_{1}),sig_{1},...,Enc(w_{n}), s i g n , E n c ( w ) ) sig_{n},Enc(w)) . â€¢ The completeness and soundness properties of the \\ac ZKP proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi play a critical role in safeguarding the aggregation process from adversarial manipulation by the aggregator. These properties ensure that the aggregator cannot deviate from the intended behaviors: â€“ If the aggregator abandons the model update generated from one client j ğ‘— j , then the aggregated results will be w ^ = âˆ‘ i = 1 , j â‰  i n w i ^ ğ‘¤ superscript subscript formulae-sequence ğ‘– 1 ğ‘— ğ‘– ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– \\hat{w}=\\sum_{i=1,j\\not=i}^{n}{w_{i}} . In this case, the corresponding circuit C â€‹ ( s â€‹ t â€‹ a â€‹ t â€‹ e â€‹ m â€‹ e â€‹ n â€‹ t , w â€‹ i â€‹ t â€‹ n â€‹ e â€‹ s â€‹ s ) ğ¶ ğ‘  ğ‘¡ ğ‘ ğ‘¡ ğ‘’ ğ‘š ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ğ‘¡ ğ‘› ğ‘’ ğ‘  ğ‘  C(statement,witness) outputs 0 0 and the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi will be invalid. â€“ If the aggregator replaces the model update generated from one client j ğ‘— j by w j ^ ^ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘— \\hat{w_{j}} , then the aggregated results will be w ^ = âˆ‘ i = 1 , j â‰  i n w i + w j ^ ^ ğ‘¤ superscript subscript formulae-sequence ğ‘– 1 ğ‘— ğ‘– ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ^ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘— \\hat{w}=\\sum_{i=1,j\\not=i}^{n}{w_{i}}+\\hat{w_{j}} . In this case, the corresponding circuit C â€‹ ( s â€‹ t â€‹ a â€‹ t â€‹ e â€‹ m â€‹ e â€‹ n â€‹ t , w â€‹ i â€‹ t â€‹ n â€‹ e â€‹ s â€‹ s ) ğ¶ ğ‘  ğ‘¡ ğ‘ ğ‘¡ ğ‘’ ğ‘š ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ğ‘¡ ğ‘› ğ‘’ ğ‘  ğ‘  C(statement,witness) outputs 0 0 and the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi will be invalid. â€“ If the aggregator inserts one fake model update generated w 0 ^ ^ subscript ğ‘¤ 0 \\hat{w_{0}} , then the aggregated results will be w ^ = âˆ‘ i = 1 n w i + w 0 ^ ^ ğ‘¤ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ^ subscript ğ‘¤ 0 \\hat{w}=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}{w_{i}}+\\hat{w_{0}} . In this case, the corresponding circuit C â€‹ ( s â€‹ t â€‹ a â€‹ t â€‹ e â€‹ m â€‹ e â€‹ n â€‹ t , w â€‹ i â€‹ t â€‹ n â€‹ e â€‹ s â€‹ s ) ğ¶ ğ‘  ğ‘¡ ğ‘ ğ‘¡ ğ‘’ ğ‘š ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ ğ‘¤ ğ‘– ğ‘¡ ğ‘› ğ‘’ ğ‘  ğ‘  C(statement,witness) outputs 0 0 and the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi will be invalid. Therefore, the proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi will only be valid if the aggregator honestly conducts the local model updates aggregation to generate the global model update w = âˆ‘ i = 1 n w i ğ‘¤ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– w=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}{w_{i}} . In zkFL , privacy is inherently ensured as only the aggregator and the participating clients are involved in the training and aggregation process, eliminating the need for external parties. As a result, only these authorized entities possess knowledge of the aggregated model updates at each round. In the context of the blockchain-based zkFL system, the blockchain miners receive encrypted the local model updates E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w i ) â€‹ ( 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– 1 ğ‘– ğ‘› Enc(w_{i})\\thickspace(1\\leq i\\leq n) , the encrypted global model update E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) , and the \\ac ZKP proof Ï€ ğœ‹ \\pi from the aggregator. However, due to the zero-knowledge property of \\ac ZKP, the miners can only verify whether E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) is correctly executed or not, without gaining any access to information about the individual local model updates w i â€‹ ( 1 â‰¤ i â‰¤ n ) subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘– 1 ğ‘– ğ‘› w_{i}\\thickspace(1\\leq i\\leq n) or the global model update w ğ‘¤ w . Additionally, storing the encrypted data of E â€‹ n â€‹ c â€‹ ( w ) ğ¸ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘¤ Enc(w) on the blockchain does not compromise the privacy of the global model update w ğ‘¤ w . Our system maintains a robust level of privacy throughout the blockchain-based zkFL process. In the following, we calculate the expected computation time of the aggregator and a client per round, to analyze the system efficiency of zkFL and blockchain-based zkFL . In both zkFL and blockchain-based zkFL systems, the aggregator is responsible for aggregating the local model updates and generating the \\ac ZKP proof. The expected computation time of the aggregator is: ğ”¼ a â€‹ g â€‹ g â€‹ r â€‹ e â€‹ g â€‹ a â€‹ t â€‹ o â€‹ r = ğ”¼ ( a g g r ) + ğ”¼ ( Z K P . g e n ) \\mathbb{E}_{aggregator}=\\mathbb{E}(aggr)+\\mathbb{E}(ZKP.gen) In the zkFL system, a client needs to train the local model, encrypt the local model update and verify the \\ac ZKP proof generated by the aggregator. The expected computation time of a client is: ğ”¼ c â€‹ l â€‹ i â€‹ e â€‹ n â€‹ t = ğ”¼ ( t r a i n ) + ğ”¼ ( e n c ) + ğ”¼ ( Z K P . v e r ) \\mathbb{E}_{client}=\\mathbb{E}(train)+\\mathbb{E}(enc)+\\mathbb{E}(ZKP.ver) In the blockchain-based zkFL system, a client still needs to train the local model and encrypt the local model update. However, the blockchain miners will take charge of verifying the \\ac ZKP proof generated by the aggregator, and the clients only need to read the data on the blockchain. The expected computation time of a client is: ğ”¼ c â€‹ l â€‹ i â€‹ e â€‹ n â€‹ t b â€‹ l â€‹ o â€‹ c â€‹ k = ğ”¼ â€‹ ( t â€‹ r â€‹ a â€‹ i â€‹ n ) + ğ”¼ â€‹ ( e â€‹ n â€‹ c ) + ğ’ª â€‹ ( 1 ) subscript superscript ğ”¼ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘œ ğ‘ ğ‘˜ ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘– ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ ğ”¼ ğ‘¡ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ”¼ ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ’ª 1 \\mathbb{E}^{block}_{client}=\\mathbb{E}(train)+\\mathbb{E}(enc)+\\mathcal{O}(1) 7 Empirical Analysis In this section, we quantify the overhead of zkFL and show that it can be used to train practical \\ac FL models. We test our zkFL system with two families of network architectures: ResNetsÂ  [ 13 ] (ResNet18, ResNet34, ResNet50) and DenseNetsÂ  [ 14 ] (DenseNet121, DenseNet169, and DenseNet201). We use this setup to evaluate the sensitivity of zkFL to network architectures and number of parameters. We use a standard Adam optimizerÂ  [ 20 ] with fixed learning rate 0.001 with batch size 50. We use the area under the receiver operating curve (AUROC) as the evaluation metric. All tests are implemented in PyTorch 1.10.1 on an NVIDIA Tesla T4 GPU with 16GB memory. For each network backbone, we conduct the tasks for zkFL with 1 1 1 , 4 4 4 , 8 8 8 , 16 16 16 , and 32 32 32 client(s). For each task, we record the training time without using zkFL , the encryption and aggregation time with zkFL , as well as the \\ac ZKP generation and verification time under zkFL . We also evaluate the performance of each task with various network backbones and client numbers. 8 Conclusion We present a novel and pioneering approach called zkFL , which utilizes \\acp ZKP to ensure a trustworthy aggregation process on the centralized aggregator. Through rigorous theoretical analysis, we establish that zkFL effectively addresses the challenge posed by a malicious aggregator during the model aggregation phase. Moreover, we extend zkFL to a blockchain-based system, significantly reducing the verification burden on the clients. The empirical analysis demonstrates that our design achieves superior levels of security and privacy compared to traditional \\ac FL systems, while maintaining a favorable training speed for the clients. These results showcase the practical feasibility and potential advantages of zkFL and its blockchain-based version in real-world applications. This work was supported in part by FLock.io under the FLock Research Grant.
  field 4
    name Content
    type string
    value Abstract \\ac FL is a machine learning paradigm, which enables multiple and decentralized clients to collaboratively train a model under the orchestration of a central aggregator. Traditional \\ac FL solutions rely on the trust assumption of the centralized aggregator, which forms cohorts of clients in a fair and honest manner. However, a malicious aggregator, in reality, could abandon and replace the clientâ€™s training models, or launch Sybil attacks to insert fake clients. Such malicious behaviors give the aggregator more power to control clients in the FL setting and determine the final training results. In this work, we introduce zkFL , which leverages zero-knowledge proofs (ZKPs) to tackle the issue of a malicious aggregator during the training model aggregation process. To guarantee the correct aggregation results, the aggregator needs to provide a proof per round. The proof can demonstrate to the clients that the aggregator executes the intended behavior faithfully. To further reduce the verification cost of clients, we employ a blockchain to handle the proof in a zero-knowledge way, where miners ( i.e. , the nodes validating and maintaining the blockchain data) can verify the proof without knowing the clientsâ€™ local and aggregated models. The theoretical analysis and empirical results show that zkFL can achieve better security and privacy than traditional \\ac FL, without modifying the underlying FL network structure or heavily compromising the training speed. 
doc 6
  field 0
    name NameDoc
    type string
    value 2312.05761.html
  field 1
    name Tittle
    type string
    value QMGeo: Differentially Private Federated Learning via Stochastic Quantization with Mixed Truncated Geometric Distribution
  field 2
    name Authors
    type string
    value Zixi Wang, M. Cenk Gursoy 
  field 3
    name Abstract
    type string
    value I Introduction The growing prevalence of machine learning (ML) applications underscores the critical need for a vast and diverse corpus of training data. Conventional centralized ML models, while effective, necessitate the central storage and processing of data, which raises significant privacy concerns and presents formidable challenges when dealing with devices and sensors equipped with limited data transmission capabilities and resources. In response to the above-mentioned challenges, federated learning (FL) has been intensively studied recently, as an approach where machine learning (ML) models of different users are jointly trained without requiring the sharing of the raw local data [ 1 ] [ 2 ] . Specifically, FL supports a distributed ML framework in which each user trains its own local ML model under the coordination of a central server, that combines the local models by requiring the users to transmit only their model updates. With the usersâ€™ datasets remaining local, FL avoids the heavy communication cost and privacy leakage of transmitting entire datasets. As mentioned above, one of the key motivations of FL structure is to reduce the communication cost. However, as modern ML applications start involving larger models, even transmitting only the model update at high precision can lay a heavy burden on communication resources, especially for edge devices whose transmission capabilities are often limited. This has led to quantization being widely used to overcome this challenge in FL. In particular, the updates from the users are first quantized into an efficient representation before the transmission [ 3 ] [ 4 ] . In addition to being a more communication-efficient scheme, another key motivation behind FL is that it alleviates privacy concerns to a degree by requiring only local processing of user data. However, while FL facilitates the usersâ€™ data to remain decentralized at the usersâ€™ local devices, this is not necessarily sufficient to ensure complete privacy. Recent studies have shown that by analyzing the model updates that get transmitted through the air [ 5 ] or just the final model itself [ 6 ] [ 7 ] , privacy leakage can occur. Differential privacy (DP) [ 8 ] is almost a de-facto mechanism used for privacy guarantees in ML applications. DP provides privacy guarantees in FL systems by introducing random perturbation to the transmitted model update, thus introducing randomness and perturbation to conceal the sensitive information about user data. DP mechanism has already been implemented in many real world applications [ 9 ] [ 10 ] [ 11 ] . We note that quantization methods lead to a certain amount of distortion in the information that the transmitted model updates were able to encode. Since DP methods ensure privacy by introducing random perturbation, the next question follows naturally: If a quantization method is stochastic, would the quantization process itself be able to provide provable DP guarantee? Our work is primarily motivated by this question. There exists studies that jointly consider reducing communication cost by quantization and providing DP guarantees. For instance, the authors in [ 12 ] propose applying the binomial mechanism with quantization to achieve both communication efficiency and differential privacy, with an improved analysis showing better utility for the binomial mechanism. [ 13 ] efficiently discretizes and flattens the model updates from the users and adds discrete Gaussian noise. However, these mechanisms still rely heavily on additional noise injection to achieve differential privacy. The authors in [ 14 ] introduce a novel mechanism where the model update information is first encoded into a parameter of a binomial distribution, and the mechanism generates samples from the distribution, without the need of additive noise. [ 15 ] also considers utilizing ternary quantization for privacy. However, their analysis applies to ternary quantization only and the DP guarantee they achieve is determined by the l ğ‘™ l -infinity norm of the model update. In this paper, we propose a novel randomized quantization method that provides DP guarantees for multiple configurations of the quantization method without relying on any additional noise injection. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows: â€¢ We propose a novel stochastic scalar quantization method QMGeo that utilizes the geometric distribution and no other additional noise to achieve Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon -DP, and we provide a RÃ©nyi DP analysis as well. â€¢ We provide privacy analysis for the QMGeo method, when applied to scalar and vector models. â€¢ We provide the optimality gap analysis to show how the FL framework converges. II Federated Learning Protocol We first discuss an FL system with N ğ‘ N clients and a parameter server (PS). The goal of such an FL system is to minimize a loss function F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ ) ğ¹ ğ’˜ F(\\boldsymbol{w}) with regard to the model parameter ğ’˜ âˆˆ â„ d ğ’˜ superscript â„ ğ‘‘ \\boldsymbol{w}\\in\\mathbb{R}^{d} . We denote the dataset that user m ğ‘š m possesses as â„¬ n subscript â„¬ ğ‘› \\mathcal{B}_{n} , and define B ğµ B as the total number of samples in the system, i.e., B = âˆ‘ n = 1 N | â„¬ n | ğµ superscript subscript ğ‘› 1 ğ‘ subscript â„¬ ğ‘› B=\\sum_{n=1}^{N}|\\mathcal{B}_{n}| . We denote the user loss function as F n = 1 | â„¬ n | â€‹ âˆ‘ ğ’– âˆˆ â„¬ n f â€‹ ( ğ’˜ , ğ’– ) subscript ğ¹ ğ‘› 1 subscript â„¬ ğ‘› subscript ğ’– subscript â„¬ ğ‘› ğ‘“ ğ’˜ ğ’– F_{n}=\\frac{1}{|\\mathcal{B}_{n}|}\\sum_{\\boldsymbol{u}\\in\\mathcal{B}_{n}}f(\\boldsymbol{w},\\boldsymbol{u}) , where ğ’– ğ’– \\boldsymbol{u} corresponds to one particular sample from the dataset â„¬ n subscript â„¬ ğ‘› \\mathcal{B}_{n} . Thus, the total loss function is given as follows: F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ ) = âˆ‘ n = 1 N | â„¬ n | B â€‹ F n â€‹ ( ğ’˜ ) . ğ¹ ğ’˜ superscript subscript ğ‘› 1 ğ‘ subscript â„¬ ğ‘› ğµ subscript ğ¹ ğ‘› ğ’˜ F(\\boldsymbol{w})=\\sum_{n=1}^{N}\\frac{|\\mathcal{B}_{n}|}{B}F_{n}(\\boldsymbol{w}). (1) An iterative approach is considered to minimize the above loss function. The PS first broadcasts the global model parameter w t subscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘¡ w_{t} to all the users. The users apply a uniform sampling to acquire the mini batch used for training with a sampling rate Îº = b â€‹ ( n ) | â„¬ n | ğœ… ğ‘ ğ‘› subscript â„¬ ğ‘› \\kappa=\\frac{{b}(n)}{|\\mathcal{B}_{n}|} , while ğ’ƒ t â€‹ ( n ) subscript ğ’ƒ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› \\boldsymbol{b}_{t}(n) is the set of samples with size b n subscript ğ‘ ğ‘› b_{n} drawn from the dataset â„¬ n subscript â„¬ ğ‘› \\mathcal{B}_{n} in iteration t ğ‘¡ t . The user n ğ‘› n acquires the gradient as ğ’ˆ t â€‹ ( n ) = âˆ‡ F n â€‹ ( ğ’˜ t , ğ’ƒ t â€‹ ( n ) ) . subscript ğ’ˆ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› âˆ‡ subscript ğ¹ ğ‘› subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ subscript ğ’ƒ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› \\boldsymbol{g}_{t}(n)=\\nabla F_{n}(\\boldsymbol{w}_{t},\\boldsymbol{b}_{t}(n)). (2) In addition, an element-wise clipping is applied to each element of the gradient ğ’ˆ t â€‹ ( n ) subscript ğ’ˆ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› \\boldsymbol{g}_{t}(n) , where each element is clipped to be within the range of [ âˆ’ W max , W max ] subscript ğ‘Š max subscript ğ‘Š max [-W_{\\text{max}},W_{\\text{max}}] : ğ’ˆ Â¯ t â€‹ ( n ) = c â€‹ l â€‹ i â€‹ p â€‹ ( ğ’ˆ t â€‹ ( n ) ) . subscript Â¯ ğ’ˆ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› ğ‘ ğ‘™ ğ‘– ğ‘ subscript ğ’ˆ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› \\bar{\\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}(n)=clip(\\boldsymbol{g}_{t}(n)). (3) The clipped gradient ğ’ˆ Â¯ t â€‹ ( n ) subscript Â¯ ğ’ˆ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› \\bar{\\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}(n) is then quantized by a quantizer Q â€‹ ( â‹… ) ğ‘„ â‹… Q(\\cdot) . The quantized vector Î” â€‹ ğ’˜ t â€‹ ( n ) = Q â€‹ ( ğ’ˆ Â¯ n â€‹ ( t ) ) Î” subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ ğ‘› ğ‘„ subscript Â¯ ğ’ˆ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ \\Delta\\boldsymbol{w}_{t}(n)=Q(\\bar{\\boldsymbol{g}}_{n}(t)) is uploaded to the PS, which then aggregates all model updates from n ğ‘› n users and update accordingly with a learning rate Î· ğœ‚ \\eta : ğ’˜ t + 1 = ğ’˜ t âˆ’ Î· â€‹ âˆ‘ n = 1 N Î” â€‹ ğ’˜ n â€‹ ( t ) . superscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ 1 superscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ ğœ‚ superscript subscript ğ‘› 1 ğ‘ Î” subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘› ğ‘¡ \\boldsymbol{w}^{t+1}=\\boldsymbol{w}^{t}-\\eta\\sum_{n=1}^{N}\\Delta\\boldsymbol{w}_{n}(t). (4) The updated global model parameter w t + 1 superscript ğ‘¤ ğ‘¡ 1 w^{t+1} is then broadcast to all the users before the next iteration. III QMGeo: Quantization Method with Mixed Geometric Distribution In this section we propose a stochastic scalar quantization method using a truncated mixed geometric distribution for the stochasticity. The quantization method considered is a scalar quantizer, quantizing the input scalar values, required to be limited within range { w | w âˆˆ [ âˆ’ W max , W max ] } conditional-set ğ‘¤ ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘Š max subscript ğ‘Š max \\{w|w\\in[-W_{\\text{max}},W_{\\text{max}}]\\} , into R ğ‘… R quantization levels. The quantizer is parameterized by the number of quantization levels R ğ‘… R and the parameter p ğ‘ p for the geometric distributions used to generate the mixed geometric distribution. We define the quantizer as Q MGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) : { w | w âˆˆ [ âˆ’ W max , W max ] } â†’ { B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( 0 ) , B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( 1 ) , â€¦ , B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( R âˆ’ 1 ) } : subscript ğ‘„ MGeo â‹… â†’ conditional-set ğ‘¤ ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘Š max subscript ğ‘Š max ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› 0 ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› 1 â€¦ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘… 1 Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(\\cdot):\\{w|w\\in[-W_{\\text{max}},W_{\\text{max}}]\\}\\rightarrow\\{Bin(0),Bin(1),\\dots,Bin(R-1)\\} . For each entry in the vector to be quantized, there would be a clipping threshold W max subscript ğ‘Š max W_{\\text{max}} , limiting the value of the corresponding entry w ğ‘¤ w to be within range [ âˆ’ W max , W max ] subscript ğ‘Š max subscript ğ‘Š max [-W_{\\text{max}},W_{\\text{max}}] . Then, for each integer r âˆˆ [ 0 , R ) ğ‘Ÿ 0 ğ‘… r\\in[0,R) , let a bin B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ Bin(r) represent the corresponding value for the r ğ‘Ÿ r -th quantization level, such that the bins evenly span the range [ âˆ’ W max , W max ] subscript ğ‘Š max subscript ğ‘Š max [-W_{\\text{max}},W_{\\text{max}}] , where B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) = âˆ’ W max + 2 â€‹ r â€‹ W max R âˆ’ 1 . ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘Š max 2 ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘Š max ğ‘… 1 \\displaystyle Bin(r)=-W_{\\text{max}}+\\frac{2rW_{\\text{max}}}{R-1}. (5) Q MGeo â€‹ ( w ) subscript ğ‘„ MGeo ğ‘¤ Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(w) takes an integer w ğ‘¤ w as input and outputs a value from the set of quantization levels { B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( 0 ) , B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( 1 ) , â€¦ , B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) , â€¦ , B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( R âˆ’ 1 ) } ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› 0 ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› 1 â€¦ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ â€¦ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘… 1 \\left\\{Bin(0),Bin(1),\\dots,Bin(r),\\dots,Bin(R-1)\\right\\} as the quantized output. The output value, i.e., the chosen quantization level B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ Bin(r) , is sampled from a mixed truncated geometric distribution determined by the value of the input integer w ğ‘¤ w . In the following part of this section, we first introduce the truncated geometric distribution, and then discuss how the truncated mixed geometric distribution is determined. The truncated geometric distribution is essentially a geometric distribution but supported only between the range of two truncation points { x | x âˆˆ â„¤ , x âˆˆ [ a , b âˆ’ 1 ] } conditional-set ğ‘¥ formulae-sequence ğ‘¥ â„¤ ğ‘¥ ğ‘ ğ‘ 1 \\{x|x\\in\\mathbb{Z},x\\in[a,b-1]\\} , where a ğ‘ a and b ğ‘ b are the left and right truncation points. In this paper, we consider only one right truncation, and thus the distribution is supported on { x | x âˆˆ â„¤ , x âˆˆ [ 1 , b âˆ’ 1 ] } conditional-set ğ‘¥ formulae-sequence ğ‘¥ â„¤ ğ‘¥ 1 ğ‘ 1 \\{x|x\\in\\mathbb{Z},x\\in[1,b-1]\\} . As in [ 16 ] , the probability mass function of a truncated geometric distribution T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ TGeo with a success probability p ğ‘ p , a failure probability of q = 1 âˆ’ p ğ‘ 1 ğ‘ q=1-p and a truncation point b ğ‘ b is P â€‹ r â€‹ { X T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o = k } = p â€‹ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) k âˆ’ 1 â‹… 1 1 âˆ’ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) b âˆ’ 1 . ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘‹ ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ ğ‘˜ â‹… ğ‘ superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘˜ 1 1 1 superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘ 1 Pr\\{X_{{TGeo}}=k\\}=p(1-p)^{k-1}\\cdot\\frac{1}{1-(1-p)^{b-1}}. (6) The mean and variance for the truncated geometric distribution T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ TGeo are E â€‹ ( X T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o ) = 1 âˆ’ b â€‹ q b âˆ’ 1 + ( b âˆ’ 1 ) â€‹ q b p â€‹ ( 1 âˆ’ q b âˆ’ 1 ) , ğ¸ subscript ğ‘‹ ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 1 ğ‘ superscript ğ‘ ğ‘ 1 ğ‘ 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘ ğ‘ 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘ 1 E(X_{TGeo})=\\frac{1-bq^{b-1}+(b-1)q^{b}}{p(1-q^{b-1})}, (7) Ïƒ T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o 2 = ( 1 + q 2 â€‹ b ) â€‹ q âˆ’ q b â€‹ ( 1 + q 2 ) â€‹ b 2 + q b + 1 â€‹ ( b 2 âˆ’ 1 ) ( 1 âˆ’ q ) 2 â€‹ ( 1 âˆ’ q b ) 2 . superscript subscript ğœ ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 2 1 superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ‘ ğ‘ superscript ğ‘ ğ‘ 1 superscript ğ‘ 2 superscript ğ‘ 2 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘ 1 superscript ğ‘ 2 1 superscript 1 ğ‘ 2 superscript 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘ 2 \\sigma_{TGeo}^{2}=\\frac{(1+q^{2b})q-q^{b}(1+q^{2})b^{2}+q^{b+1}(b^{2}-1)}{(1-q)^{2}(1-q^{b})^{2}}. (8) We define a w ğ‘¤ w centered mixed truncated geometric distribution as follows: X MTGeo = { B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r âˆ’ ( X G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 1 âˆ’ 1 ) ) w.p. p mix B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r + X G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 2 ) otherwise subscript ğ‘‹ MTGeo cases ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘‹ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 1 1 w.p. subscript ğ‘ mix ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘‹ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 2 otherwise missing-subexpression X_{\\text{MTGeo}}=\\left\\{\\begin{array}[]{rcl}Bin\\left(r-(X_{{Geo1}}-1)\\right)&\\text{w.p.}&p_{\\text{mix}}\\\\ Bin\\left(r+X_{{Geo2}}\\right)&\\text{otherwise}\\\\ \\end{array}\\right.\\\\ (9) where p mix = w âˆ’ B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r + 1 ) âˆ’ B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) subscript ğ‘ mix ğ‘¤ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ 1 ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ p_{\\text{mix}}=\\frac{w-Bin(r)}{Bin(r+1)-Bin(r)} , and X T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 1 âˆ’ 1 subscript ğ‘‹ ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 1 1 X_{{TGeo1}}-1 and X T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 2 âˆ’ 1 subscript ğ‘‹ ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 2 1 X_{{TGeo2}}-1 are random variables sampled from two different truncated geometric distributions, G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 1 â€‹ ( p ) ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 1 ğ‘ {Geo1}(p) and G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 2 â€‹ ( p ) ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 2 ğ‘ {Geo2}(p) . The mixture probability is determined by the distance from w ğ‘¤ w to B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ Bin(r) and B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r + 1 ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ 1 Bin(r+1) respectively, where B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ Bin(r) and B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r + 1 ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ 1 Bin(r+1) are the neighboring quantization levels to w ğ‘¤ w . Since both the input and the output of the quantization scheme has a range of [ âˆ’ W max , W max ] subscript ğ‘Š max subscript ğ‘Š max [-W_{\\text{max}},W_{\\text{max}}] , we are forced to use truncated geometric distributions to sample to decided quantization level. Thus, X âˆ¼ T â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 1 â€‹ ( p ) similar-to ğ‘‹ ğ‘‡ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 1 ğ‘ X\\sim{TGeo1}(p) is supported only on { 1 , 2 , â€¦ , r + 1 } 1 2 â€¦ ğ‘Ÿ 1 \\{1,2,\\dots,r+1\\} and X âˆ¼ TGeo2 â€‹ ( p ) similar-to ğ‘‹ TGeo2 ğ‘ X\\sim\\text{TGeo2}(p) is supported only on { 1 , 2 , â€¦ , R âˆ’ r âˆ’ 1 } 1 2 â€¦ ğ‘… ğ‘Ÿ 1 \\{1,2,\\dots,R-r-1\\} . We obtain the truncated geometric distributions by normalizing the probability mass on the support back to 1 1 1 , where the geometric distribution itself is parameterized by the success probability p ğ‘ p : P â€‹ r â€‹ { X G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 1 = k } = p â€‹ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) k âˆ’ 1 â‹… 1 1 âˆ’ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) r , ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘‹ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 1 ğ‘˜ â‹… ğ‘ superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘˜ 1 1 1 superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘Ÿ Pr\\{X_{{Geo1}}=k\\}=p(1-p)^{k-1}\\cdot\\frac{1}{1-(1-p)^{r}}, (10) P â€‹ r â€‹ { X G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ 2 = k } = p â€‹ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) k âˆ’ 1 â‹… 1 1 âˆ’ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) R âˆ’ r âˆ’ 2 . ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘‹ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ 2 ğ‘˜ â‹… ğ‘ superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘˜ 1 1 1 superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘… ğ‘Ÿ 2 Pr\\{X_{{Geo2}}=k\\}=p(1-p)^{k-1}\\cdot\\frac{1}{1-(1-p)^{R-r-2}}. (11) The mixed geometric distribution assigns non-zero probabilities to every quantization level, providing the randomness needed to achieve differential privacy. We control the shape of the distribution with parameter p ğ‘ p . In particular, the larger p ğ‘ p is, the more skewed the distribution becomes, focusing the probability mass to neighboring quantization levels, thus less variance introduced by the Q MGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ‘„ MGeo â‹… Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(\\cdot) mechanism, as demonstrated in Fig 1 . IV Differential Privacy Analysis for QMGeo We first give the following definitions regarding DP [ 8 ] . Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon - differential privacy: For any two adjacent datasets D , D â€² âˆˆ ğ’Ÿ ğ· superscript ğ· â€² ğ’Ÿ D,D^{{}^{\\prime}}\\in\\mathcal{D} , and any output set of ğ’® âŠ‚ â„› ğ’® â„› \\mathcal{S}\\subset\\mathcal{R} with domain ğ’Ÿ ğ’Ÿ \\mathcal{D} and range â„› â„› \\mathcal{R} , and randomized mechanism â„³ : ğ’Ÿ â†’ â„› : â„³ â†’ ğ’Ÿ â„› \\mathcal{M}:\\mathcal{D}\\rightarrow\\mathcal{R} that satisfies ( Ïµ , Î´ ) italic-Ïµ ğ›¿ (\\epsilon,\\delta) - differential privacy, the following property must hold: P â€‹ r â€‹ [ â„³ â€‹ ( D ) âˆˆ ğ’® ] â‰¤ e Ïµ â€‹ P â€‹ r â€‹ [ â„³ â€‹ ( D â€² ) âˆˆ ğ’® ] . ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] â„³ ğ· ğ’® superscript ğ‘’ italic-Ïµ ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] â„³ superscript ğ· â€² ğ’® Pr[\\mathcal{M}(D)\\in\\mathcal{S}]\\leq e^{\\epsilon}Pr[\\mathcal{M}(D^{{}^{\\prime}})\\in\\mathcal{S}]. (12) We note that more commonly, DP mechanism use the concept of ( Ïµ , Î´ ) italic-Ïµ ğ›¿ (\\epsilon,\\delta) -DP, where Î´ ğ›¿ \\delta is essentially a relaxation term that allows some arbitrarily small probability for the DP mechanism to fail. ( Î± , Ïµ ) ğ›¼ italic-Ïµ (\\alpha,\\epsilon) -RÃ©nyi Differential Privacy (RDP) : For any two adjacent datasets D , D â€² âˆˆ ğ’Ÿ ğ· superscript ğ· â€² ğ’Ÿ D,D^{{}^{\\prime}}\\in\\mathcal{D} , and any output set of ğ’® âŠ‚ â„› ğ’® â„› \\mathcal{S}\\subset\\mathcal{R} with domain ğ’Ÿ ğ’Ÿ \\mathcal{D} and range â„› â„› \\mathcal{R} , and randomized mechanism â„³ : ğ’Ÿ â†’ â„› : â„³ â†’ ğ’Ÿ â„› \\mathcal{M}:\\mathcal{D}\\rightarrow\\mathcal{R} that satisfies ( Î± , Ïµ ) ğ›¼ italic-Ïµ (\\alpha,\\epsilon) -RDP, the following must hold: D Î± ( P â„³ â€‹ ( D ) | | P â„³ â€‹ ( D â€² ) ) â‰¤ Ïµ , D_{\\alpha}\\left(P_{\\mathcal{M}(D)}||P_{\\mathcal{M}(D^{{}^{\\prime}})}\\right)\\leq\\epsilon, (13) where D Î± ( P â„³ â€‹ ( D ) | | P â„³ â€‹ ( D â€² ) ) D_{\\alpha}\\left(P_{\\mathcal{M}(D)}||P_{\\mathcal{M}(D^{{}^{\\prime}})}\\right) is the RÃ©nyi divergence, given by D Î± ( P | | Q ) = 1 Î± âˆ’ 1 log ğ”¼ x âˆ¼ Q [ ( P â€‹ ( x ) Q â€‹ ( x ) ) Î± ] . D_{\\alpha}(P||Q)=\\frac{1}{\\alpha-1}\\log\\mathbb{E}_{x\\sim Q}\\left[\\left(\\frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}\\right)^{\\alpha}\\right]. (14) We first establish the guarantee that a scalar stochastic k ğ‘˜ k -level quantization provides as a comparison. We next establish the per-element differential privacy the scalar QMGeo method provides in Section IV-B . We then extend the analysis to the differential privacy guarantee when applied to a model update vector. The stochastic k ğ‘˜ k -level quantization is a quantization method that randomly assigns the value w ğ‘¤ w to neighboring quantization levels, where the probability is determined by the distance from w ğ‘¤ w to its neighboring quantization levels. The stochastic k ğ‘˜ k -level quantization, similar to the Q MGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ‘„ MGeo â‹… Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(\\cdot) , requires the input scalar values to be limited within some range { w | w âˆˆ [ âˆ’ W max , W max ] } conditional-set ğ‘¤ ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘Š max subscript ğ‘Š max \\{w|w\\in[-W_{\\text{max}},W_{\\text{max}}]\\} and the bins evenly span the range: B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) = âˆ’ W max + 2 â€‹ r â€‹ W max R âˆ’ 1 . ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘Š max 2 ğ‘Ÿ subscript ğ‘Š max ğ‘… 1 \\displaystyle Bin(r)=-W_{\\text{max}}+\\frac{2rW_{\\text{max}}}{R-1}. (15) The quantization is done as follows: Q â€‹ ( w ) = { B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r + 1 ) w.p. w âˆ’ B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r + 1 ) âˆ’ B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) otherwise. ğ‘„ ğ‘¤ cases ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ 1 w.p. ğ‘¤ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ 1 ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ otherwise. missing-subexpression Q(w)=\\left\\{\\begin{array}[]{rcl}Bin\\left(r+1\\right)&\\text{w.p.}&\\frac{w-Bin(r)}{Bin(r+1)-Bin(r)}\\\\ Bin\\left(r\\right)&\\text{otherwise.}\\\\ \\end{array}\\right.\\\\ (16) For number of quantization levels larger than 3, the stochastic k ğ‘˜ k -level quantization faces a difficulty providing DP, as it could only quantize values to their neighboring quantization levels. When analysing the DP performance, it is obvious that if g ğ‘” g and g â€² superscript ğ‘” â€² g^{{}^{\\prime}} do not lie in neighboring intervals, there will always be a choice of v ğ‘£ v that achieves the worst case rendering one of the probability terms to 0 and nonzero for the other. For instance, when v ğ‘£ v is a neighboring quantization level v = B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r ) ğ‘£ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ v=Bin(r) to g ğ‘” g but not for g â€² superscript ğ‘” â€² g^{{}^{\\prime}} , Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon cannot be unbounded. An example is provided in Fig 2 , where the intuition is that, since the quantization method quantizes to only neighboring quantization levels, there is not enough randomness to achieve DP for a number of quantization levels larger than 3. However, for ternary quantization, such method could provide DP guarantees to some extent [ 15 ] : e Ïµ â€‹ P â€‹ r â€‹ [ ğ’¬ â€‹ ( g â€² ) = v ] superscript ğ‘’ italic-Ïµ ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] ğ’¬ superscript ğ‘” â€² ğ‘£ \\displaystyle e^{\\epsilon}Pr[\\mathcal{Q}(g^{{}^{\\prime}})=v] â‰¤ P â€‹ r â€‹ [ ğ’¬ â€‹ ( g ) = v ] absent ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] ğ’¬ ğ‘” ğ‘£ \\displaystyle\\leq Pr[\\mathcal{Q}(g)=v] (17) e Ïµ Ã— 0 superscript ğ‘’ italic-Ïµ 0 \\displaystyle e^{\\epsilon}\\times 0 â‰¤ g âˆ’ v B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( r + 1 ) âˆ’ v . absent ğ‘” ğ‘£ ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘Ÿ 1 ğ‘£ \\displaystyle\\leq\\frac{g-v}{Bin(r+1)-v}. (18) We first consider the Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon -DP analysis. In our case, the considered randomized mechanism is essentially the quantization method that determines the vectors sent from the usersâ€™ devices. Thus, we consider the following inequality: P â€‹ r â€‹ [ ğ’¬ MGeo â€‹ ( g ) = v ] â‰¤ e Ïµ â€‹ P â€‹ r â€‹ [ ğ’¬ MGeo â€‹ ( g â€² ) = v ] . ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] subscript ğ’¬ MGeo ğ‘” ğ‘£ superscript ğ‘’ italic-Ïµ ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] subscript ğ’¬ MGeo superscript ğ‘” â€² ğ‘£ Pr[\\mathcal{Q_{\\text{MGeo}}}(g)=v]\\leq e^{\\epsilon}Pr[\\mathcal{Q_{\\text{MGeo}}}(g^{{}^{\\prime}})=v]. (19) ( 19 ) should hold for any v ğ‘£ v , where g ğ‘” g and g â€² superscript ğ‘” â€² g^{{}^{\\prime}} are entries of gradients acquired from arbitrary neighboring datasets of a particular user. We note that the worst case scenario occurs when v ğ‘£ v is either B â€‹ ( 0 ) ğµ 0 B(0) or B â€‹ ( R âˆ’ 1 ) ğµ ğ‘… 1 B(R-1) , g ğ‘” g and g â€² superscript ğ‘” â€² g^{{}^{\\prime}} is equal to B â€‹ ( 0 ) ğµ 0 B(0) and B â€‹ ( R âˆ’ 1 ) ğµ ğ‘… 1 B(R-1) respectively. Without loss of generality, we assume v = B â€‹ ( 0 ) ğ‘£ ğµ 0 v=B(0) , g = B â€‹ ( 0 ) ğ‘” ğµ 0 g=B(0) and g â€² = B â€‹ ( R âˆ’ 1 ) superscript ğ‘” â€² ğµ ğ‘… 1 g^{{}^{\\prime}}=B(R-1) . Substituting the values in ( 19 ) with the probability mass of the mixed truncated geometric distribution, we obtain P â€‹ r â€‹ [ Q MGeo â€‹ ( g ) = v ] P â€‹ r â€‹ [ Q MGeo â€‹ ( g â€² ) = v ] ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] subscript ğ‘„ MGeo ğ‘” ğ‘£ ğ‘ƒ ğ‘Ÿ delimited-[] subscript ğ‘„ MGeo superscript ğ‘” â€² ğ‘£ \\displaystyle\\frac{Pr[Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(g)=v]}{Pr[Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(g^{{}^{\\prime}})=v]} â‰¤ e Ïµ absent superscript ğ‘’ italic-Ïµ \\displaystyle\\leq e^{\\epsilon} (20) 1 2 1 2 â€‹ p â€‹ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) R âˆ’ 2 1 2 1 2 ğ‘ superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘… 2 \\displaystyle\\frac{\\frac{1}{2}}{\\frac{1}{2}p(1-p)^{R-2}} â‰¤ e Ïµ absent superscript ğ‘’ italic-Ïµ \\displaystyle\\leq e^{\\epsilon} (21) Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\displaystyle\\epsilon â‰¤ âˆ’ ln â¡ p â€‹ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) R âˆ’ 2 absent ğ‘ superscript 1 ğ‘ ğ‘… 2 \\displaystyle\\leq-\\ln{p(1-p)^{R-2}} = âˆ’ ( ln â¡ p + ( R âˆ’ 2 ) â€‹ ln â¡ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) ) . absent ğ‘ ğ‘… 2 1 ğ‘ \\displaystyle=-(\\ln{p}+(R-2)\\ln{(1-p))}. We demonstrate the trade-off between the achieved DP level Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon and the parameters of the Q â€‹ M â€‹ G â€‹ e â€‹ o â€‹ ( â‹… ) ğ‘„ ğ‘€ ğº ğ‘’ ğ‘œ â‹… QMGeo(\\cdot) , the number of quantization levels r ğ‘Ÿ r and the success probability p ğ‘ p of the mixed truncated geometric distribution. Fig 3 demonstrates how the achieved DP level Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon changes as the parameter p ğ‘ p of Q QMGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ‘„ QMGeo â‹… Q_{\\text{QMGeo}}(\\cdot) changes for fixed numbers of quantization levels. Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon increases rapidly as p ğ‘ p approaches 1, where at p = 1 ğ‘ 1 p=1 , the Q QMGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ‘„ QMGeo â‹… Q_{\\text{QMGeo}}(\\cdot) reduces to a conventional stochastic r ğ‘Ÿ r -level quantization which could not achieve DP except for when quantizing to 3 levels or less. As shown in ( 20 ), Ïµ italic-Ïµ \\epsilon increases linearly with the number of quantization levels R ğ‘… R . With the quasi-convex property of the RÃ©nyi divergence, we can show the worst case scenario is attained by the extremal points where two input elements each sit at B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( 0 ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› 0 Bin(0) and B â€‹ i â€‹ n â€‹ ( R âˆ’ 1 ) ğµ ğ‘– ğ‘› ğ‘… 1 Bin(R-1) , where the two discrete distributions are essentially a standard truncated geometric distribution X ğ‘‹ X and a slightly altered one, X â€² = âˆ’ X + R + 1 superscript ğ‘‹ â€² ğ‘‹ ğ‘… 1 X^{{}^{\\prime}}=-X+R+1 , sharing the same parameter of success rate p ğ‘ p and supported on the same set of quantization levels. We then substitute parameters R ğ‘… R , p ğ‘ p from the ğ’¬ MGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ’¬ MGeo â‹… \\mathcal{Q}_{\\text{MGeo}(\\cdot)} into ( 13 ) and obtain D Î± ( P â„³ â€‹ ( D ) | | P â„³ â€‹ ( D â€² ) ) â‰¤ D Î± ( P X | | P X â€² ) \\displaystyle D_{\\alpha}\\left(P_{\\mathcal{M}(D)}||P_{\\mathcal{M}(D^{{}^{\\prime}})}\\right)\\leq D_{\\alpha}\\left(P_{X}||P_{X^{{}^{\\prime}}}\\right) (22) = 1 Î± âˆ’ 1 â€‹ log â¡ { ( âˆ‘ i = 1 R ( p â€‹ q i âˆ’ 1 â€‹ 1 1 âˆ’ q R âˆ’ 1 ) Î± ( q R + 1 âˆ’ i â€‹ p â€‹ 1 1 âˆ’ q R âˆ’ 1 ) Î± âˆ’ 1 ) } absent 1 ğ›¼ 1 superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘… superscript ğ‘ superscript ğ‘ ğ‘– 1 1 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘… 1 ğ›¼ superscript superscript ğ‘ ğ‘… 1 ğ‘– ğ‘ 1 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘… 1 ğ›¼ 1 \\displaystyle=\\frac{1}{\\alpha-1}\\log\\left\\{\\left(\\sum_{i=1}^{R}\\frac{\\left(pq^{i-1}\\frac{1}{1-q^{R-1}}\\right)^{\\alpha}}{\\left(q^{R+1-i}p\\frac{1}{1-q^{R-1}}\\right)^{\\alpha-1}}\\right)\\right\\} (23) = 1 1 âˆ’ Î± â€‹ log â¡ { ( p â€‹ q âˆ’ 2 â€‹ Î± + ( 1 âˆ’ Î± ) â€‹ R + 1 1 âˆ’ q R âˆ’ 1 ) â€‹ Î± â€‹ ( q ( 2 â€‹ Î± âˆ’ 1 ) â€‹ R âˆ’ 1 ) q ( 2 â€‹ Î± âˆ’ 1 ) âˆ’ 1 } absent 1 1 ğ›¼ ğ‘ superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 ğ›¼ ğ‘… 1 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘… 1 ğ›¼ superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 ğ‘… 1 superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 1 \\displaystyle=\\frac{1}{1-\\alpha}\\log\\left\\{\\left(\\frac{pq^{-2\\alpha+(1-\\alpha)R+1}}{1-q^{R-1}}\\right)\\frac{\\alpha\\left(q^{(2\\alpha-1)R}-1\\right)}{q^{(2\\alpha-1)}-1}\\right\\} (24) where q = 1 âˆ’ p ğ‘ 1 ğ‘ q=1-p . Thus, we have Ïµ â€‹ ( Î± ) â‰¤ 1 1 âˆ’ Î± â€‹ log â¡ { p â€‹ q âˆ’ 2 â€‹ Î± + ( 1 âˆ’ Î± ) â€‹ R + 1 1 âˆ’ q R âˆ’ 1 â‹… Î± â€‹ ( q ( 2 â€‹ Î± âˆ’ 1 ) â€‹ R âˆ’ 1 ) q ( 2 â€‹ Î± âˆ’ 1 ) âˆ’ 1 } . italic-Ïµ ğ›¼ 1 1 ğ›¼ â‹… ğ‘ superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 ğ›¼ ğ‘… 1 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘… 1 ğ›¼ superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 ğ‘… 1 superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 1 \\epsilon(\\alpha)\\leq\\frac{1}{1-\\alpha}\\log\\left\\{\\frac{pq^{-2\\alpha+(1-\\alpha)R+1}}{1-q^{R-1}}\\cdot\\frac{\\alpha\\left(q^{(2\\alpha-1)R}-1\\right)}{q^{(2\\alpha-1)}-1}\\right\\}. (25) Fig. 4 plots the Ïµ â€‹ ( Î± ) italic-Ïµ ğ›¼ \\epsilon(\\alpha) curve obtained with a ğ’¬ MGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ’¬ MGeo â‹… \\mathcal{Q}_{\\text{MGeo}}(\\cdot) with R = 8 ğ‘… 8 R=8 and p = 0.5 ğ‘ 0.5 p=0.5 . For any individual agentâ€™s gradient, we apply the scalar Q QMGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ‘„ QMGeo â‹… Q_{\\text{QMGeo}}(\\cdot) to every element in the gradient. The entire privacy mechanism can be viewed as a function of multiple Q QMGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ‘„ QMGeo â‹… Q_{\\text{QMGeo}}(\\cdot) mechanisms. Thus, for a gradient vector ğ’ˆ = ( g 1 , g 2 , â€¦ , g d ) ğ’ˆ subscript ğ‘” 1 subscript ğ‘” 2 â€¦ subscript ğ‘” ğ‘‘ \\boldsymbol{g}=(g_{1},g_{2},...,g_{d}) the final quantized model update is ( Q QMGeo â€‹ ( g 1 ) , Q QMGeo â€‹ ( g 2 ) , â€¦ , Q QMGeo â€‹ ( g d ) ) subscript ğ‘„ QMGeo subscript ğ‘” 1 subscript ğ‘„ QMGeo subscript ğ‘” 2 â€¦ subscript ğ‘„ QMGeo subscript ğ‘” ğ‘‘ \\left(Q_{\\text{QMGeo}}(g_{1}),Q_{\\text{QMGeo}}(g_{2}),...,Q_{\\text{QMGeo}}(g_{d})\\right) . Considering the privacy amplification theorem [ 17 ] and the random sampling in Section II , according to the sequential composition theorem of DP, the overall DP guarantee we obtain for the model update vector with dimension d ğ‘‘ d and sampling rate Îº ğœ… \\kappa is Ïµ â‰¤ âˆ’ d â€‹ Îº â€‹ ( ln â¡ p + ( R âˆ’ 2 ) â€‹ ln â¡ ( 1 âˆ’ p ) ) . italic-Ïµ ğ‘‘ ğœ… ğ‘ ğ‘… 2 1 ğ‘ \\epsilon\\leq-d\\kappa(\\ln{p}+(R-2)\\ln{(1-p)}). (26) Similarly, RDP shows a composition of the same pattern [ 18 ] . From [ 19 ] , for Î± â‰¤ 2 ğ›¼ 2 \\alpha\\leq 2 , the RDP enjoys Ïµ sampled â€‹ ( Î± ) = ğ’ª â€‹ ( Îº 2 â€‹ Ïµ â€‹ ( Î± ) ) subscript italic-Ïµ sampled ğ›¼ ğ’ª superscript ğœ… 2 italic-Ïµ ğ›¼ \\epsilon_{\\text{sampled}}(\\alpha)=\\mathcal{O}(\\kappa^{2}\\epsilon(\\alpha)) , where Îº ğœ… \\kappa is the sampling rate. Applying to ( 25 ), we have Ïµ â€‹ ( Î± ) â‰¤ italic-Ïµ ğ›¼ absent \\displaystyle\\epsilon(\\alpha)\\leq Îº 2 d 1 1 âˆ’ Î± Ã— \\displaystyle\\kappa^{2}d\\frac{1}{1-\\alpha}\\times (27) log â¡ { p â€‹ q âˆ’ 2 â€‹ Î± + ( 1 âˆ’ Î± ) â€‹ R + 1 1 âˆ’ q R âˆ’ 1 â‹… Î± â€‹ ( q ( 2 â€‹ Î± âˆ’ 1 ) â€‹ R âˆ’ 1 ) q ( 2 â€‹ Î± âˆ’ 1 ) âˆ’ 1 } . â‹… ğ‘ superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 ğ›¼ ğ‘… 1 1 superscript ğ‘ ğ‘… 1 ğ›¼ superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 ğ‘… 1 superscript ğ‘ 2 ğ›¼ 1 1 \\displaystyle\\log\\left\\{\\frac{pq^{-2\\alpha+(1-\\alpha)R+1}}{1-q^{R-1}}\\cdot\\frac{\\alpha\\left(q^{(2\\alpha-1)R}-1\\right)}{q^{(2\\alpha-1)}-1}\\right\\}. V Optimality Gap We next characterize how the perturbation introduced by the randomized quantization method impact the convergence performance by characterizing the optimality gap between F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ T ) ğ¹ subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘‡ F(\\boldsymbol{w}_{T}) (the loss value achieved at global iteration T ğ‘‡ T ) and F âˆ— superscript ğ¹ F^{*} , the optimal loss value. We introduce two assumptions for this purpose. L ğ¿ L -smoothness is assumed for the loss function F ğ¹ F . (Polyak-Lojosiewicz Inequality) We assume that the loss function F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ ) ğ¹ ğ’˜ F(\\boldsymbol{w}) satisfies the Polyak-Lojosiewicz (PL) condition: 1 2 â€‹ â€– âˆ‡ F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ ) â€– 2 â‰¥ Î¼ â€‹ [ F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ ) âˆ’ F âˆ— ] . 1 2 superscript norm âˆ‡ ğ¹ ğ’˜ 2 ğœ‡ delimited-[] ğ¹ ğ’˜ superscript ğ¹ \\frac{1}{2}\\|\\nabla F(\\boldsymbol{w})\\|^{2}\\geq\\mu[F(\\boldsymbol{w})-F^{*}]. (28) We abuse the notation of Q MGeo â€‹ ( ğ’ˆ t ) subscript ğ‘„ MGeo subscript ğ’ˆ ğ‘¡ Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(\\boldsymbol{g}_{t}) a bit in this section to represent the operation of applying scalar Q MGeo â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript ğ‘„ MGeo â‹… Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(\\cdot) to every element in the vector. We define ğœ¹ t = Q MGeo â€‹ ( ğ’ˆ t ) âˆ’ âˆ‡ F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ t ) subscript ğœ¹ ğ‘¡ subscript ğ‘„ MGeo subscript ğ’ˆ ğ‘¡ âˆ‡ ğ¹ subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ \\boldsymbol{\\delta}_{t}=Q_{\\text{MGeo}}(\\boldsymbol{g}_{t})-\\nabla F(\\boldsymbol{w}_{t}) , to characterize the perturbation introduced by the randomized quantization. Following the first steps of [ 20 ] and taking ğœ¹ t subscript ğœ¹ ğ‘¡ \\boldsymbol{\\delta}_{t} into account, we have F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ t + 1 ) ğ¹ subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ 1 \\displaystyle F(\\boldsymbol{w}_{t+1}) â‰¤ F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ t ) + âˆ‡ F â€‹ ( ğ’˜ t ) T â€‹ ( ğ’˜ t + 1 âˆ’ ğ’˜ t ) absent ğ¹ subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ âˆ‡ ğ¹ superscript subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ ğ‘‡ subscript ğ’˜ ğ‘¡ 1 subscript ğ’˜
