We denote the final function as Coref â¢ ( â‹… , â‹… ) Coref â‹… â‹… \\textsc{Coref}(\\cdot,\\cdot) Coref ( â‹… , â‹… ) for brevity. We adopt the training scheme proposed by Kirstain etÂ al. ( 2021 ) , which filters spans to avoid the explicit enumeration of all possible mention spans, and represents antecedent relations using only the endpoints of the retained spans with a biaffine transformation. At the training stage, we minimize the negative log-likelihood of predicting clusters â„’ Coref = âˆ’ âˆ‘ ( ğ“’ , ğ’™ ) âˆˆ ğ’Ÿ Coref log â¢ âˆ s âˆˆ ğ’® âˆ‘ ğ’œ âˆˆ a â¢ ( ğ“’ ) p â¢ ( ğ’œ s | s , ğ’™ ) , subscript â„’ Coref subscript ğ“’ ğ’™ subscript ğ’Ÿ Coref subscript product ğ‘  ğ’® subscript ğ’œ ğ‘ ğ“’ ğ‘ conditional subscript ğ’œ ğ‘  ğ‘  ğ’™ \\displaystyle\\mathcal{L}_{\\textsc{Coref}}=-\\!\\!\\!\\!\\!\\!\\sum_{\\boldsymbol{(% \\mathcal{C}},\\boldsymbol{x})\\in\\mathcal{D}_{\\textsc{Coref}}}\\!\\!\\!\\!\\!\\!\\log% \\prod_{s\\in\\mathcal{S}}\\sum_{\\mathcal{A}\\in a(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}})}p(% \\mathcal{A}_{s}|s,\\boldsymbol{x}), caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Coref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_( bold_caligraphic_C , bold_italic_x ) âˆˆ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Coref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_log âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A âˆˆ italic_a ( bold_caligraphic_C ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ( caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s , bold_italic_x ) , (9) where ğ’Ÿ Coref subscript ğ’Ÿ Coref \\mathcal{D}_{\\textsc{Coref}} caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Coref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a training data for coreference resolution. 3 Context-Aware MT with Coreference Information Our motivation stems from the observation that when translating a paragraph, translators are able to pick up precise words and explain why a particular choice of word is better given the context especially by relying on linguistic cues such as discourse structure, verb equivalence, etc. Thus, instead of modeling a translation by directly relying on an additional conditional variable of coreference clusters ğ“’ ğ“’ \\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}} bold_caligraphic_C for ğ’™ ğ’™ \\boldsymbol{x} bold_italic_x , i.e., p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ“’ , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ“’ ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_caligraphic_C , bold_italic_x ) , we propose a model that is akin to the noisy channel framework Yee etÂ al. ( 2019 ) , to explain the decision ğ’š ğ’š \\boldsymbol{y} bold_italic_y made by the translation model : p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ“’ , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ“’ ğ’™ \\displaystyle p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_caligraphic_C , bold_italic_x ) = p â¢ ( ğ’š , ğ“’ | ğ’™ ) p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’™ ) = p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’™ ) absent ğ‘ ğ’š conditional ğ“’ ğ’™ ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’™ ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’™ \\displaystyle=\\frac{p(\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{x})}% {p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{x})}=\\frac{p(\\boldsymbol{y}|% \\boldsymbol{x})(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x})}{p(% \\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{x})} = divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_italic_y , bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_x ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_x ) end_ARG âˆ p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) â¢ p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) , proportional-to absent ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ \\displaystyle\\propto p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{x})p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}% }|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}), âˆ italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) , (10) where p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) is a model to predict coreference clusters given both an input sentence and its translation. Note that we can omit the denominator p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_x ) given that it is a constant when predicting ğ’š ğ’š \\boldsymbol{y} bold_italic_y , similar to the noisy channel modeling, since both ğ’™ ğ’™ \\boldsymbol{x} bold_italic_x and ğ“’ ğ“’ \\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}} bold_caligraphic_C are input to our model. The direct model p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ“’ , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ“’ ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_caligraphic_C , bold_italic_x ) is prone to ignore features in ğ“’ ğ“’ \\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}} bold_caligraphic_C , especially when the context is long, since the information in ğ’™ ğ’™ \\boldsymbol{x} bold_italic_x has direct correspondence with ğ’š ğ’š \\boldsymbol{y} bold_italic_y . In contrast, the model for coreference resolution task, p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) , will explain the coreference cluster information in ğ’™ ğ’™ \\boldsymbol{x} bold_italic_x not only by the features from ğ’™ ğ’™ \\boldsymbol{x} bold_italic_x but additional features from ğ’š ğ’š \\boldsymbol{y} bold_italic_y and, thus, the higher p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) , the more likely ğ’š ğ’š \\boldsymbol{y} bold_italic_y will be a translation for ğ’™ ğ’™ \\boldsymbol{x} bold_italic_x . When coupled with the translation model p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) especially when jointly trained together, our formulation will be able to capture long-distance relations in coreference clusters since the coreference resolution task needs to predict it given ğ’™ ğ’™ \\boldsymbol{x} bold_italic_x and ğ’š ğ’š \\boldsymbol{y} bold_italic_y . The two sub-models, i.e., p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) and p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) , could be trained separately as done in a noisy channel modeling approach of MT (Yee etÂ al., 2019 ) . This work formulates it as a multi-task setting by predicting two tasks jointly, i.e., translation task and coreference resolution task, by using the representations of the encoder and decoder of Vaswani etÂ al. ( 2017 ) . More specifically, we do not alter translation task p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) , but obtain the representation for the coreference task by fusing the representations of the encoder and decoder as follows p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ \\displaystyle p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) = âˆ s âˆˆ ğ’® âˆ‘ ğ’œ âˆˆ a â¢ ( ğ“’ ) Coref â¢ ( ğ’œ s , s ; ğ‡ â€² c â¢ o â¢ r â¢ e â¢ f ) absent subscript product ğ‘  ğ’® subscript ğ’œ ğ‘ ğ“’ Coref subscript ğ’œ ğ‘  ğ‘  subscript superscript ğ‡ â€² ğ‘ ğ‘œ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘’ ğ‘“ \\displaystyle=\\prod_{s\\in\\mathcal{S}}\\sum_{\\mathcal{A}\\in a(\\boldsymbol{% \\mathcal{C}})}\\textsc{Coref}(\\mathcal{A}_{s},s;\\mathbf{H^{\\prime}}_{coref}) = âˆ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s âˆˆ caligraphic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_A âˆˆ italic_a ( bold_caligraphic_C ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Coref ( caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s ; bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_o italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ğ‡ â€² c â¢ o â¢ r â¢ e â¢ f subscript superscript ğ‡ â€² ğ‘ ğ‘œ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘’ ğ‘“ \\displaystyle\\mathbf{H^{\\prime}}_{coref} bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_o italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = Dec â¢ ( ğ‘¯ e â¢ n â¢ c l e , ğ‘¯ d â¢ e â¢ c l d ) . absent Dec superscript subscript ğ‘¯ ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘™ ğ‘’ superscript subscript ğ‘¯ ğ‘‘ ğ‘’ ğ‘ subscript ğ‘™ ğ‘‘ \\displaystyle=\\textsc{Dec}(\\boldsymbol{H}_{enc}^{l_{e}},\\boldsymbol{H}_{dec}^{% l_{d}}). = Dec ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_n italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (11) Note that we obtain ğ‡ â€² c â¢ o â¢ r â¢ e â¢ f subscript superscript ğ‡ â€² ğ‘ ğ‘œ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘’ ğ‘“ \\mathbf{H^{\\prime}}_{coref} bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_o italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from an additional decoder layer for the encoder representation ğ‘¯ e â¢ n â¢ c l e superscript subscript ğ‘¯ ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘™ ğ‘’ \\boldsymbol{H}_{enc}^{l_{e}} bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_n italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with cross attention for ğ‘¯ d â¢ e â¢ c l d superscript subscript ğ‘¯ ğ‘‘ ğ‘’ ğ‘ subscript ğ‘™ ğ‘‘ \\boldsymbol{H}_{dec}^{l_{d}} bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . We jointly train our two sub-models using the label-smoothing variant of the cross-entropy loss function in Equation 6 and the marginal log-likelihood loss function in Equation 9 , but using ğ‡ â€² c â¢ o â¢ r â¢ e â¢ f subscript superscript ğ‡ â€² ğ‘ ğ‘œ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘’ ğ‘“ \\mathbf{H^{\\prime}}_{coref} bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_o italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Equation 3 as follows â„’ = â„’ MT + Î± â¢ â„’ â€² Coref , â„’ subscript â„’ MT ğ›¼ subscript superscript â„’ â€² Coref \\displaystyle\\mathcal{L}=\\mathcal{L}_{\\textsc{MT}}+\\alpha\\mathcal{L^{\\prime}}_% {\\textsc{Coref}}, caligraphic_L = caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT MT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_Î± caligraphic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT Coref end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (12) where Î± ğ›¼ \\alpha italic_Î± is a hyperparameter that controls a contribution of the coreference resolution task. During the training step, we feed pairs of sentences together with coreference cluster information generated by an external coreference resolution framework since human annotation is not available in MT tasks. Inference is complex in that the model for the coreference resolution task has to be evaluated every time a target token is generated by the translation model as done in the noisy channel approach of MT (Yee etÂ al., 2019 ) . We resort to a simpler approach of ignoring the term for coreference clusters, i.e., p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{\\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) , and using only the token prediction, i.e., p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) ; alternatively, we generate a large set of N ğ‘ N italic_N -best translations from p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{x}) italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) and rerank them using the joint probabilities log â¡ p â¢ ( ğ’š | ğ’™ ) + Î² â¢ log â¡ p â¢ ( ğ“’ | ğ’š , ğ’™ ) , ğ‘ conditional ğ’š ğ’™ ğ›½ ğ‘ conditional ğ“’ ğ’š ğ’™ \\displaystyle\\log{p(\\boldsymbol{y}|\\boldsymbol{x})}+\\beta\\log{p(\\boldsymbol{% \\mathcal{C}}|\\boldsymbol{y},\\boldsymbol{x}}), roman_log italic_p ( bold_italic_y | bold_italic_x ) + italic_Î² roman_log italic_p ( bold_caligraphic_C | bold_italic_y , bold_italic_x ) , (13) where Î² ğ›½ \\beta italic_Î² is a hyperparameter to control the strength of the coreference resolution task. 4 Experiments We utilized the En-Ru dataset (Voita etÂ al., 2019 ) and the widely adopted En-De benchmark dataset IWSLT 2017, as used in Maruf etÂ al. ( 2019 ) , with details provided in Table 1 . We also used the multilingual TED talk dataset (Qi etÂ al., 2018 ) to assess the efficacy of our proposed method across a variety of language types, including different characteristics in pronouns, word order and gender assignment with specifics delineated in Table 2 . The En-Ru dataset comes from OpenSubtitle 2018 (Lison etÂ al., 2018 ) by sampling training instances with three context sentences after tokenization and, thus, no document boundary information is preserved. In the En-De and multilingual datasets, document boundaries are provided. To maintain consistency in our translation settings during experiments, we tokenize all texts by using MeCab 1 1 1 https://taku910.github.io/mecab/ for Japanese, Jieba 2 2 2 https://github.com/fxsjy/jieba for Chinese, VnCoreNLP Vu etÂ al. ( 2018 ) for Vietnamse and the spaCy framework 3 3 3 https://spacy.io for all other languages. We also apply a sliding window with a size of m ğ‘š m italic_m sentences ( m = 4 ğ‘š 4 m=4 italic_m = 4 ) to each document to create a similar format to that of the En-Ru dataset. For the first m âˆ’ 1 ğ‘š 1 m-1 italic_m - 1 sentences, which do not have enough m âˆ’ 1 ğ‘š 1 m-1 italic_m - 1 context sentences in the m ğ‘š m italic_m -to- m ğ‘š m italic_m translation settings, we pad the beginning of these sentences with empty sentences, ensuring m âˆ’ 1 ğ‘š 1 m-1 italic_m - 1 context sentences for all samples in the dataset. For preprocessing, we apply the BPE (Byte-Pair Encoding) technique from Sennrich etÂ al. ( 2016 ) with 32K merging operations to all datasets. To identify coreference clusters for the source language, i.e., English, we leveraged the AllenNLP framework 4 4 4 https://allenai.org and employed the SpanBERT large model (Lee etÂ al., 2018 ) . After generating sub-word units, we adjust the word-wise indices of all members in coreference clusters using the offsets for sub-word units. In our experiments, we adopt the context-aware translation settings ( m ğ‘š m italic_m -to- m ğ‘š m italic_m with m = 4 ğ‘š 4 m=4 italic_m = 4 ) utilized in previous works (Zhang etÂ al., 2020 ) . For the context-agnostic setting, we translate each sentence individually. We adopt the Transformer model (Vaswani etÂ al., 2017 ) as our two baselines: Base Sent , which was trained on source and target sentence pairs without context, and Base Doc , which was trained with contexts in the m ğ‘š m italic_m -to- m ğ‘š m italic_m setting as described in Â§ 2.2 . To make a fair comparison with previous works that use similar context-aware translation settings and enhance MT system at the encoder side, we employ the G-Transformer (Bao etÂ al., 2021 ) , Hybrid Context (Zheng etÂ al., 2020 ) and MultiResolution (Sun etÂ al., 2022 ) . We also compare our approach with the CoDoNMT (Lei etÂ al., 2022 ) model, which also integrates coreference resolution information to improve translation quality. Note that all aforementioned baselines utilize provided open-source code. Additionally, we trained a simple variant of a context-aware Transformer model similar to Base Doc, but differ in that it incorporated a coreference embedding, alongside the existing positional embedding, directly in to the encoder side of the model (Trans+C-Embedding ). This coreference embedding is derived from the original positional embedding in the encoder with the modification that all tokens within a coreference cluster share the same value as the left-most token in the same cluster. Note that it is intended as a simple baseline for a direct model as discussed in Â§ 3 . We evaluate our proposed inference methods, including the original inference method in Transformer without reranking ( Trans+ Coref ) or with reranking with the score from our sub-model ( Trans+ Coref +RR ) using the coreference resolution task as denoted in Equation 13 . All models in our experiments were trained on a machine with the following specifications: an AMD EPYC 7313P CPU, 256GB RAM, a single NVIDIA RTX A6000 with 48GB VRAM, and CUDA version 11.3. For multilingual experiments, we used a single NVIDIA RTX 3090 GPU, Intel i9-10940X, 48GB VRAM and CUDA version 12.1. We use the same parameters, including the number of training epochs, learning rate, batch size, etc., for all models in our experiments. Specifically, we train all models for 40 epochs when both losses of coreference and translation in the valid set show unchanging or no improvements. For translation tasks, we use the Adam optimizer with Î² 1 = 0.9 subscript ğ›½ 1 0.9 \\beta_{1}=0.9 italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.9 , Î² 2 = 0.98 subscript ğ›½ 2 0.98 \\beta_{2}=0.98 italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.98 and Ïµ = 1 â¢ e âˆ’ 9 italic-Ïµ 1 ğ‘’ 9 \\epsilon=1e-9 italic_Ïµ = 1 italic_e - 9 , along with an inverse square root learning rate scheduler. All dropout values are set to 0.1, and the learning rate is set to 7 â¢ e âˆ’ 5 7 ğ‘’ 5 7e-5 7 italic_e - 5 . We use a batch size of 128 and 32 for experiments on the English-Russian and English-German datasets, respectively. Other parameters follow those in Vaswani etÂ al. ( 2017 ) . For coreference tasks, we adopt parameters from Kirstain etÂ al. ( 2021 ) , with some modifications to accommodate our GPU memory. We use the Adam optimizer with Î² 1 = 0.9 subscript ğ›½ 1 0.9 \\beta_{1}=0.9 italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.9 , Î² 2 = 0.98 subscript ğ›½ 2 0.98 \\beta_{2}=0.98 italic_Î² start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.98 and Ïµ = 1 â¢ e âˆ’ 9 italic-Ïµ 1 ğ‘’ 9 \\epsilon=1e-9 italic_Ïµ = 1 italic_e - 9 , with a learning rate of 7 â¢ e âˆ’ 5 7 ğ‘’ 5 7e-5 7 italic_e - 5 . Dropout value is set to 0.3, top lambda (the percentage of all spans to keep after filtering) is set to 0.4, hidden size is set to 512, and the maximum span length is set to 10. The maximum cluster value s are set to 8 and 20 for the English-Russian and English-German datasets, respectively. To rerank the N-best translations, we use Equation 13 and perform a grid search on the validation set with a step size of 0.0001 0.0001 0.0001 0.0001 to select the optimal value for Î² ğ›½ \\beta italic_Î² from âˆ’ 2 2 -2 - 2 to 2 2 2 2 . We employ SacreBLEU (Post, 2018 ) as an automated evaluation metric to assess the quality of translations in our experiments. We follow Yuan etÂ al. ( 2021 ) and use the mbart-large-50 model ( mBART ) 5 5 5 https://huggingface.co/facebook/mbart-large-50 to compute the average BARTScore of all translation to measure semantic equivalence and coherence between references and translations. In this metric, the higher value, the better semantic equivalence and coherence. We also utilize the COMET 6 6 6 COMET-20 model ( wmt20-COMET-da ) metric (Rei etÂ al., 2020 ) , a neural network-based measure, since it is highly correlated to human judgement in prior work by Freitag etÂ al. ( 2022 ) . With statistically significant ( Koehn , 2004 ) at p ğ‘ p italic_p < 0.01 compared to other systems. The main results of our experiments are presented in Table 3 . Our results indicate that training the baseline Transformer model with both context and target sentences (Base Doc) results in better performance than training with only target sentences (Base Sent) in the En-Ru dataset. This finding is consistent with those reported by Voita etÂ al. ( 2019 ) , in which more contextual information is helpful to achieve better translation. However, in the En-De dataset, the Base Doc system performs worse compared to the Base Sent system. This discrepancy can be explained by the different methodologies used in constructing the En-De and En-Ru datasets. For the En-De datasets, both context-aware and context-agnostic datasets are compiled from the same pool of non-duplicate sentences. However, for the En-Ru datasets, the context-agnostic dataset is created by removing context sentences from the context-aware dataset (Voita etÂ al., 2019 ) , which results in varying numbers of non-duplicate sentences between these context-agnostic and context-aware datasets. When comparing our systems with the Transformer model (Base Doc), our approaches, both Trans+ Coref and Trans+ Coref +RR, have proven effective in enhancing translation quality by explaining the decision of translation through predicting coreference information. This is demonstrated by the superior BLEU scores ( + 0.52 0.52 +0.52 + 0.52 in En-Ru and + 2.06 2.06 +2.06 + 2.06 in En-De for the Trans+ Coref +RR), BARTScore and COMET observed when comparing across different settings and language pairs. Compared to the G-Transformer system described in Bao etÂ al. ( 2021 ) , our system shows an improvement in both inference approaches (Trans+ Coref and Trans+ Coref +RR). In the En-Ru dataset, our system achieves a higher BLEU score by + 0.24 0.24 +0.24 + 0.24 , while in the En-De dataset, it demonstrates a larger improvement of + 1.14 1.14 +1.14 + 1.14 in the same metric (Trans+ Coref ). Additionally, our method outperforms the G-Transformer in terms of the BARTScore and COMET for both the En-Ru and En-De datasets. One possible explanation for these results is that the G-Transformer is specifically designed to map each sentence in the source language to only a single sentence in the target language during both training and inference steps. This design choice helps mitigating issues related to generating very long sequences. However, when the dataset size is small, as in the case of the En-De dataset, the G-Transformer encounters difficulties in selecting useful information. In contrast, our approach effectively selects useful information indirectly through the coreference explanation sub-model, especially when dealing with small-sized datasets, which allows our system to outperform under the scenarios with limited dataset size. Our method also surpasses the Transformer model with additional position embedding (Trans+C-Embedding), which relied on coreference information using a direct modeling approach. In the results of the multilingual TED talk dataset in Table 4 , where we compare our proposed method to Transformer models and the best baselines in Table 3 , our method also surpasses other baselines within + 1.0 1.0 +1.0 + 1.0 to + 2.3 2.3 +2.3 + 2.3 BLEU scores. These findings provide further evidence that our approach is effective in improving translation quality and can be applied to diverse language types. We provide an example of translations from our systems as well as other baseline systems in Table 5 . In this example, the correct translation of the phrase in the last sentence, Ğ¼Ğ¾ĞµĞ¹ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğ¾Ğ¹ ( my team ), is determined by identifying which word refers to "my" , in this case, i and me . Both the G-Transformer and Trans+C-Embedding systems fail to capture these mentions and consequently produce an incorrect translation, Ğ¼Ğ¾Ñ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ñƒ . Despite correctly translating Ğ¼Ğ¾ĞµĞ¹ , the Base Doc systemâ€™s phrase Ğ²ÑÑ‚Ñ€ĞµÑ‚Ğ¸Ğ¼ÑÑ Ğ² Ğ¼Ğ¾ĞµĞ¹ ĞºĞ¾Ğ¼Ğ°Ğ½Ğ´Ğµ is grammatically incorrect and deviates from the original English "meet my team" . Conversely, our systems capture this reference accurately, yielding a translation consistent with the reference. 5 Analysis We conducted experiments by adjusting the value of Î± ğ›¼ \\alpha italic_Î± in Equation 12 during the training of the Trans+ Coref without reranking. The experimental results in Table 6 indicate that for medium-sized corpora, selecting a value of Î± ğ›¼ \\alpha italic_Î± that is either too small or too large negatively impacts translation quality. The optimal range for Î± ğ›¼ \\alpha italic_Î± is 0.8 â‰¤ Î± â‰¤ 2 0.8 ğ›¼ 2 0.8\\leq\\alpha\\leq 2 0.8 â‰¤ italic_Î± â‰¤ 2 . We conducted a study on coreference explanation on the En-De dataset (Maruf etÂ al., 2019 ) with coreference cluster information as in Â§ 4.1 by ablating the information from the translation so that it conditions only on the input information (Trans+ Enc ). This setting can be regarded as a conventional multi-task setting in which coreference on the input-side is predicted together with its translation. Specifically, we replace the input representation for coreference resolution sub-model from Dec â¢ ( â‹… ) Dec â‹… \\textsc{Dec}(\\cdot) Dec ( â‹… ) in Equation 3 to Enc â¢ ( â‹… ) Enc â‹… \\textsc{Enc}(\\cdot) Enc ( â‹… ) in Equation 14 as follows ğ‡ â€²â€² c â¢ o â¢ r â¢ e â¢ f = Enc â¢ ( ğ‘¯ e â¢ n â¢ c l e ) . subscript superscript ğ‡ â€²â€² ğ‘ ğ‘œ ğ‘Ÿ ğ‘’ ğ‘“ Enc superscript subscript ğ‘¯ ğ‘’ ğ‘› ğ‘ subscript ğ‘™ ğ‘’ \\displaystyle\\mathbf{H^{\\prime\\prime}}_{coref}=\\textsc{Enc}(\\boldsymbol{H}_{% enc}^{l_{e}}). bold_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_o italic_r italic_e italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = Enc ( bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_n italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (14) As shown in Table 7 , the conventional multi-task learning setting of Trans+ Enc performed lower than Trans+ Coref , which indicates the benefits of fusing information from the predicted translation. The MUC metric counts the changes required to align the systemâ€™s entity groupings with the gold-standard, focusing on adjustments to individual references. We further examine the entity heat maps derived from self-attention weights of both the translation and coreference sub-models in Base Doc, Trans+ Enc , and Trans+ Coref systems for the input "I _0 hate that you _0 â€™re leaving . Well , Grandma â€™s not doing well . So you _1 have to drop everything to go take care of her ? Yes , William , I _1 do ." from the human annotated test set from Voita etÂ al. ( 2019 ) . In this particular example, the coreference clusters are defined as [I _0 , William], [you _0 , you _1 , I _1 ] , and [Grandma, her] . To provide visual representations, we depict the average self-attention values from the last encoder layer of these three systems. This choice is based on their tendency to focus more on semantic or abstract information (Clark etÂ al., 2019 ) . Figure 1 displays the entity heat maps, which illustrate the behavior of self-attention in different systems in the translation sub-model. In the Base Doc system, self-attention primarily concentrates on local sentences while disregarding information between sentences. In contrast, the Trans+ Enc system exhibits the ability to focus on inter-sentences. However, when it comes to tokens within coreference clusters, the focused values are incorrect for certain clusters, such as [I _0 , William] . On the other hand, the Trans+ Coref system not only exhibits inter-sentential focus in its self-attention heat map but also accurately depicts the focused values for tokens within coreference clusters. Figure 2 demonstrates the entity heat maps in the coreference sub-model. In the Trans+ Enc system, self-attention mainly concentrates on entities within the local scope and immediate adjacent sentences. However, when comparing these high attention values with links in the coreference clusters, a significant proportion is found to be incorrect, i.e., [Grandma; I _1 ] . On the other hand, the self-attention in Trans+ Coref exhibits a more balanced distribution of focus across all entities within the input. This balanced distribution results in considerably fewer errors when compared to self-attention in the Trans+ Enc system. These findings align with the MUC metric (Vilain etÂ al., 1995 ) , which is based on the minimum number of missing links in the response entities compared to the key entities, with details, particularly the F1 score, provided in Table 7 . Note that we use reference translations to form ğ‘¯ d â¢ e â¢ c l d superscript subscript ğ‘¯ ğ‘‘ ğ‘’ ğ‘ subscript ğ‘™ ğ‘‘ \\boldsymbol{H}_{dec}^{l_{d}} bold_italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in Equation 3 for identifying coreference clusters. Additionally, we generate gold label coreference clusters using the AllenNLP framework, as discussed in Section 4.1 . We conducted experiments with the Coref (Trans+ Coref ) and the Transformer (Base Doc) systems by exploring different context sizes in m ğ‘š m italic_m -to- m ğ‘š m italic_m settings ranging from 2 2 2 2 to 4 4 4 4 . The experimental results in Figure 3 demonstrate that the Base Doc system significantly drops the translation quality when the context gets longer, while Trans+ Coref consistently achieves gains as we incorporate more contexts. This result also indicates the use of the coreference sub-model is able to capture contextual information better than the baseline. We conduct experiments by reranking all translation hypotheses with varying beam sizes during inference by the Equation 13 to assess the impact of coreference explanation sub-model on the En-Ru dataset (Voita etÂ al., 2019 ) . Figure 4 illustrates the results of our experiments measured by BLEU score. Our findings indicate that reranking with the sub-model Coref yields improved results, with differences ranging from 0.02 to 0.09. We also report oracle BLEU score in Figure 5 , which is measured by selecting a hypothesis sentence that gives the maximum sentence-BLEU scores among potential hypotheses, to verify the potentially correct translations in an N ğ‘ N italic_N -best list. The results of this experiment with differences ranging from 0.2 to 0.4 suggest that using the sub-model Coref has more potential to generate correct translations. Despite the relatively minor difference in the oracle BLEU score between the Trans+ Coref and the Base Doc systems, indicating a similarity in their candidate space, the beam search process yields better results with the Trans+ Coref when compared with the Base Doc system. This reflects the differences in BLEU scores between Trans+ Coref and Base Doc. The performance gap in the BLEU score between the Trans+ Coref and Trans+ Coref +RR could potentially be further maximized by incorporating the coreference resolution during the beam search at the expense of more computational costs. We intend to explore this possibility in our future research endeavors. To further understand the impact of the coreference explanation sub-model on translation results, we perform an experiment on the contrastive test in Voita etÂ al. ( 2019 ) , which contains human-labeled sentences to evaluate discourse phenomena and relies on the source text only, to verify whether our method can solve phenomena at the document level. Table 8 presents the results this experiment, which indicate that our system outperforms the Base Doc system in all aspects. These results demonstrate the significant contribution of the coreference explanation sub-model to the MT system. We carried out experiments to assess the impact of varying accuracies within the external coreference framework, which was reported in 80.4% of the F1 score on MUC metric for English CoNLL-2012 shared task in Lee etÂ al. ( 2018 ) , on the overall translation quality. This was achieved by randomly omitting members from coreference clusters while ensuring that each valid cluster retained a minimum of two members, i.e., removing you _1 from the cluster [you _0 , you _1 , I _1 ] in Figure 1 . Table 9 presents the outcomes of these experiments, where a slight reduction in translation quality is observed as members of coreference clusters are randomly dropped. Remarkably, even with the omission of up to half of the cluster members, the results continue to exceed the performance of the Base Doc system. This implies that our method could be robust and effective, particularly for languages with limited accuracy in coreference resolution tasks. We randomly sampled training instances from the En-Ru dataset and varied the sample sizes to 200,000 (comparable size to the En-De dataset), 500,000, and 1,000,000. Subsequently, we evaluated the contribution of the Coref sub-model (Trans+ Coref ) and the Transformer (Base Doc) on these datasets of different sample sizes. Figure 6 illustrates the results of these experiments. Our proposed system outperforms the Transformer model (Base Doc) across all sample sizes in the test set. Notably, this improvement is not limited to the small dataset size setting but similar trends are observed for medium-sized datasets. These results indicate that our system consistently outperforms the transformer model and achieves improved translation qualities regardless of the dataset size. While our proposed method and existing works enhance translation accuracy for certain linguistic phenomena, challenges persist, particularly in handling deixis. Unlike straightforward scenarios where additional context aids in accurately translating deictic terms (e.g., determining the speakers in a conversation to correctly translate the words I and You ), some instances require a comprehensive understanding of the provided textâ€™s content to achieve correct pronoun translation. Consider the following example from the test data of the English-Vietnamese dataset (Qi etÂ al., 2018 ) : "Oh my god! youâ€™re right! who can w â¢ e [chÃºng ta] ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘’ [chÃºng ta] we_{\\text{[chÃºng ta]}} italic_w italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [chÃºng ta] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sue? Now Chris is a really brilliant lawyer, but he knew almost nothing about patent law and certainly nothing about genetics. I knew something about genetics, but I wasnâ€™t even a lawyer, let alone a patent lawyer. So clearly w â¢ e [chÃºng tÃ´i] ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘’ [chÃºng tÃ´i] we_{\\text{[chÃºng tÃ´i]}} italic_w italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [chÃºng tÃ´i] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT had a lot to learn before w â¢ e [chÃºng ta] ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘’ [chÃºng ta] we_{\\text{[chÃºng ta]}} italic_w italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [chÃºng ta] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT could file a lawsuit." In this context, the English word we is translated as either chÃºng tÃ´i ( w â¢ e [chÃºng tÃ´i] ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘’ [chÃºng tÃ´i] we_{\\text{[chÃºng tÃ´i]}} italic_w italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [chÃºng tÃ´i] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) or chÃºng ta ( w â¢ e [chÃºng ta] ğ‘¤ subscript ğ‘’ [chÃºng ta] we_{\\text{[chÃºng ta]}} italic_w italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [chÃºng ta] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , reflecting the exclusion or inclusion of the listener. This example underscores the importance of contextual nuances in translating pronouns like we or us from English to Vietnamese, where the choice between chÃºng tÃ´i and chÃºng ta is critical. Building on the insights from the described example, we extracted all samples that presented similar linguistic challenges, in which a correctly translated sample must ensure that every instance of the word we is accurately translated. Table 10 presents the accuracy of translating the word we into the correct Vietnamese. While our method surpasses other baseline models in performance, it still exhibits lower accuracy in comparison to the deixis-related outcomes of the contrastive test for Russian (Voita etÂ al., 2019 ) . This discrepancy highlights the phenomenon as a significant challenge that warrants further investigation. We present a detailed comparison of the parameter count and training time per epoch for our proposed method alongside other baselines in Table 11 . When compared to the G-Transformer, our method uses fewer parameters, takes less time to train, and yet achieves better performance. On the other hand, the Base Doc system uses the fewest parameters and trains the quickest, but its results are notably underperforming. 6 Related Works Multi-task learning has primarily been utilized in MT tasks to integrate external knowledge into MT systems. Luong etÂ al. ( 2016 ); Niehues and Cho ( 2017 ); Eriguchi etÂ al. ( 2017 ) have employed multi-task learning with different variations of shared weights of encoders, decoders, or attentions between tasks to effectively incorporate parsing knowledge into sequence-to-sequence MT systems. For incorporating coreference cluster information, Ohtani etÂ al. ( 2019 ) , Xu etÂ al. ( 2021 ) and Lei etÂ al. ( 2022 ) incorporate coreference cluster information to improve their NMT models. Ohtani etÂ al. ( 2019 ) integrates coreference cluster information into a graph-based NMT approach to enhance the information. Similarly, Xu etÂ al. ( 2021 ) uses the information to connect words across different sentences and incorporates other parsing information to construct a graph at the document-level, resulting in an improvement in translation quality. Lei etÂ al. ( 2022 ) employs coreference information to construct cohesion maskings and fune-tunes sentence MT systems to produce more cohesive outputs. On the other hand, Stojanovski and Fraser ( 2018 ); Hwang etÂ al. ( 2021 ) leverage coreference cluster information through augmented steps. They either add noise to construct a coreference-augmented dataset or use coreference information to create a contrastive dataset and train their MT systems on these enhanced datasets to achieve better translation performance. For context-aware MT, Kuang etÂ al. ( 2018 ) and Tu etÂ al. ( 2018 ) focus on utilizing memory-augmented neural networks, which store and retrieve previously translated parts in NMT systems. These approaches help unify the translation of objects, names, and other elements across different sentences in a paragraph. In contrast, Xiong etÂ al. ( 2019 ); Voita etÂ al. ( 2019 ) develop a multiple-pass decoding method inspired by the Deliberation Network Xia etÂ al. ( 2017 ) to address coherence issues, i.e., deixis and ellipsis in paragraphs. They first translate the source sentences in the first pass and then correct the translations to improve coherence in the second pass. Mansimov etÂ al. ( 2020 ) introduce a self-training technique, similar to domain self-adaptation, to develop a document-level NMT system. Meanwhile, various methods aim to encapsulate contextual information, i.e., hierachical attention (Maruf etÂ al., 2019 ) , multiple-attention mechanism (Zhang etÂ al., 2020 ; Bao etÂ al., 2021 ) , recurrent memory unit (Feng etÂ al., 2022 ) 7 7 7 In Feng etÂ al. ( 2022 ) , they provided source code without instructions. We tried to reuse and reimplement their method; however, we can not reproduce their results in any efforts. They did not reply our emails for asking training details. We therefore decide not to include their results in Table 3 . . In a data augmentation approach, Bao etÂ al. ( 2023 ) diversify training data for the target side language, rather than only using a single human translation for each source document. Recently, Wang etÂ al. ( 2023 ) has shown that state-of-the-art Large Language Models (LLMs), i.e. GPT-4 (OpenAI etÂ al., 2024 ) , outperform traditional translation models in context-aware MT. In other approaches, Wu etÂ al. ( 2024 ) and Li etÂ al. ( 2024 ) have developed effective fine-tuning and translation methods for lightweight LLMs; however, the efficacy of NMT models can exceed that of lightweight LLMs, varying by language pair. 7 Conclusion This study presents a context-aware MT model that explains the translation output by predicting coreference clusters in the source side. The model comprises two sub-models, a translation sub-model and a coreference resolution sub-model, with no modifications to the translation model. The coreference resolution sub-model predicts coreference clusters by fusing the representation from both the encoder and decoder to capture relations in the two languages explicitly. Under the same settings of the En-Ru, En-De and the multilingual datasets, and following analyses on the coreference sub-modelâ€™s contributions, the impacts of context and corpus size, as well as the type of information utilized in the sub-model, our proposed method has proven effective in enhancing translation quality. Limitations In this study, the hidden dimension size in the coreference resolution sub-model is smaller than typical state-of-the-art systems, i.e., 512 vs. 2048, potentially limiting its accuracy and negatively impacting the quality of translation. Additionally, this study requires fine-tuning for a certain hyperparameter that combines the coreference resolution sub-model and the translation model to achieve satisfactory results. Acknowledgements The authors are grateful to the anonymous reviewers and the Action Editor who provided many insightful comments that improve the paper. This work was supported by JSPS KAKENHI Grant Number JP21H05054.
  field 4
    name Content
    type string
    value Abstract Despite significant improvements in enhancing the quality of translation, context-aware machine translation (MT) models underperform in many cases. One of the main reasons is that they fail to utilize the correct features from context when the context is too long or their models are overly complex. This can lead to the explain-away effect, wherein the models only consider features easier to explain predictions, resulting in inaccurate translations. To address this issue, we propose a model that explains the decisions made for translation by predicting coreference features in the input. We construct a model for input coreference by exploiting contextual features from both the input and translation output representations on top of an existing MT model. We evaluate and analyze our method in the WMT document-level translation task of English-German dataset, the English-Russian dataset, and the multilingual TED talk dataset, demonstrating an improvement of over 1.0 BLEU score when compared with other context-aware models.

  field 3
    name Abstract
    type string
    value 1 Introduction Federated learning (FL) is a distributed training approach for machine learning models, where multiple clients collaborate under the guidance of a central server to optimize a loss function (KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al., 2016 ; McMahan etÂ al., 2017 ) . This method allows clients to contribute to model training while keeping their data private, as it avoids the need for direct data sharing. Often, federated optimization is formulated as the minimization of a finite-sum objective function, min x âˆˆ â„ d â¡ { f â€‹ ( x ) := 1 n â€‹ âˆ‘ i = 1 n f i â€‹ ( x ) } , subscript ğ‘¥ superscript â„ ğ‘‘ assign ğ‘“ ğ‘¥ 1 ğ‘› superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– ğ‘¥ \\min_{x\\in\\mathbb{R}^{d}}\\left\\{f(x):=\\frac{1}{n}\\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(x)\\right\\}, (1) where each f i : â„ d â†¦ â„ : subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– maps-to superscript â„ ğ‘‘ â„ f_{i}:\\mathbb{R}^{d}\\mapsto\\mathbb{R} is the empirical risk of model x ğ‘¥ x associated with the i ğ‘– i -th client. The federated averaging method ( FedAvg ) is among the most favored strategies for addressing federated learning problems, as proposed by McMahan etÂ al. ( 2017 ); Mangasarian and Solodov ( 1993 ) . In FedAvg , the server initiates an iteration by selecting a subset of clients for participation in a given round. Each chosen client then proceeds with local training, employing gradient-based techniques like gradient descent ( GD ) or stochastic gradient descent ( SGD ) with random reshuffling, as discussed by Bubeck etÂ al. ( 2015 ); Gower etÂ al. ( 2019 ); Moulines and Bach ( 2011 ); Sadiev etÂ al. ( 2022 ) . Li etÂ al. ( 2020 ) proposed replacing the local training of each client via SGD in FedAvg with the computation of a proximal term, resulting in the FedProx algorithm. x k + 1 = 1 n â€‹ âˆ‘ i = 1 n prox Î³ â€‹ f i â€‹ ( x k ) , subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ 1 1 ğ‘› superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript prox ğ›¾ subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ x_{k+1}=\\frac{1}{n}\\sum_{i=1}^{n}{\\rm prox}_{\\gamma f_{i}}\\left(x_{k}\\right), (2) where Î³ > 0 ğ›¾ 0 \\gamma>0 is the step size, and the proximal operator is defined as prox Î³ â€‹ f i â€‹ ( x ) := arg â¡ min z âˆˆ â„ d â¡ { f i â€‹ ( z ) + 1 2 â€‹ Î³ â€‹ â€– z âˆ’ x â€– 2 } . assign subscript prox ğ›¾ subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– ğ‘¥ subscript ğ‘§ superscript â„ ğ‘‘ subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– ğ‘§ 1 2 ğ›¾ superscript norm ğ‘§ ğ‘¥ 2 {\\rm prox}_{\\gamma f_{i}}\\left(x\\right):=\\arg\\min_{z\\in\\mathbb{R}^{d}}\\left\\{f_{i}\\left(z\\right)+\\frac{1}{2\\gamma}\\left\\|z-x\\right\\|^{2}\\right\\}. Contrary to gradient-based methods like GD and SGD , algorithms based on proximal operation, such as proximal point method ( PPM ) (Rockafellar, 1976 ; Parikh etÂ al., 2014 ) and stochastic proximal point methods ( SPPM ) (Asi and Duchi, 2019 ; Bertsekas, 2011 ; Khaled and Jin, 2022 ; Patrascu and Necoara, 2018 ; RichtÃ¡rik and TakÃ¡c, 2020 ) benefit from stability against inaccuracies in learning rate specification (Ryu and Boyd, 2014 ) . Indeed, for GD and SGD , a step size that is excessively large can result in divergence of the algorithm, whereas a step size that is too small can significantly deteriorate the convergence rate of the algorithm. PPM was formally introduced and popularized by the seminal paper of Rockafellar ( 1976 ) to solve the variational inequality problems. In practice, the stochastic variant SPPM is more frequently used. It is known that the proximal operator applied to a proper, closed and convex function can be viewed as the projection to some level set of the same function depending on the value of Î³ ğ›¾ \\gamma . In particular, if we let each f i subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– f_{i} be the indicator function of a nonempty closed convex set ğ’³ i subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– \\mathcal{X}_{i} , then prox Î³ â€‹ f i â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript prox ğ›¾ subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– â‹… {\\rm prox}_{\\gamma f_{i}}\\left(\\cdot\\right) becomes the projection Î  ğ’³ i â€‹ ( â‹… ) subscript Î  subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– â‹… \\Pi_{\\mathcal{X}_{i}}(\\cdot) onto the set ğ’³ i subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– \\mathcal{X}_{i} . In this case, FedProx in ( 2 ) becomes the parallel projection method for convex feasibility problem (Censor etÂ al., 2001 , 2012 ; Combettes, 1997a ; Necoara etÂ al., 2019 ) , if we additionally assume ğ’³ := â‹‚ i = 1 n ğ’³ i â‰  âˆ… . assign ğ’³ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– \\mathcal{X}:=\\bigcap_{i=1}^{n}\\mathcal{X}_{i}\\neq\\emptyset. A well known fact about the parallel projection method is that its empirical efficiency can often be improved by extrapolation (Combettes, 1997a ; Necoara etÂ al., 2019 ) . This involves moving further along the line that connects the last iterate x k subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ x_{k} and the average projection point, resulting in the iteration x k + 1 = x k + Î± k â€‹ ( 1 n â€‹ âˆ‘ i = 1 n Î  ğ’³ i â€‹ ( x k ) âˆ’ x k ) , subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ 1 subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ 1 ğ‘› superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript Î  subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ x_{k+1}=x_{k}+\\alpha_{k}\\left(\\frac{1}{n}\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\Pi_{\\mathcal{X}_{i}}\\left(x_{k}\\right)-x_{k}\\right), (3) where Î± k â‰¥ 1 subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ 1 \\alpha_{k}\\geq 1 defines extrapolation level. Despite the various heuristic rules proposed over the years for setting Î± k subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ \\alpha_{k} (Bauschke etÂ al., 2006 ; Censor etÂ al., 2001 ; Combettes, 1997b ) , which have demonstrated satisfactory practical performance, it was only recently that the theoretical foundation explaining the success of extrapolation techniques for solving convex feasibility problems was unveiled by Necoara etÂ al. ( 2019 ) , where the authors considered randomized version of ( 3 ) named Randomized Projection Method ( RPM ). The practical success of extrapolation has spurred numerous extensions of existing algorithms. Notably, Jhunjhunwala etÂ al. ( 2023 ) combined FedAvg with extrapolation, resulting in FedExP , leveraging insights from an effective heuristic rule (Combettes, 1997b ) for setting Î± k subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ \\alpha_{k} as follows: Î± k = âˆ‘ i = 1 n â€– x k âˆ’ Î  ğ’³ i â€‹ ( x k ) â€– 2 â€– âˆ‘ i = 1 n ( x k âˆ’ Î  ğ’³ i â€‹ ( x k ) ) â€– 2 . subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› superscript norm subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ subscript Î  subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ 2 superscript norm superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ subscript Î  subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ 2 \\alpha_{k}=\\frac{\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\left\\|x_{k}-\\Pi_{\\mathcal{X}_{i}}(x_{k})\\right\\|^{2}}{\\left\\|\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\left(x_{k}-\\Pi_{\\mathcal{X}_{i}}(x_{k})\\right)\\right\\|^{2}}. (4) However, the authors did not consider the case of a constant extrapolation parameter, nor did they disclose the relationship between the extrapolation parameter and the stepsize of SGD . The extrapolation parameter can be viewed as a server side stepsize in the context of federated learning, its effectiveness was discussed by Malinovsky etÂ al. ( 2023 ) . In the field of fixed point methods, extrapolation is also known as over-relaxation (Rechardson, 1911 ) . It is a technique used to effectively accelerate the convergence of fixed point methods, including gradient algorithms and proximal splitting algorithms (Iutzeler and Hendrickx, 2019 ; Condat etÂ al., 2023 ) . Our paper contributes in the following ways; for the notations used please refer to Appendix Â  A . â€¢ Based on the insights gained from the convex feasibility problem, we extend FedProx to its extrapolated counterpart FedExProx for both convex and strongly 1 1 1 Strongly convex: f ğ‘“ f is Î¼ ğœ‡ \\mu -strongly convex. convex interpolation problems (See Table Â  1 ). We reveal the dependence of the optimal extrapolation parameter on smoothness, indicating that simply averaging the iterates from local training on the server is suboptimal. Instead, extrapolation should be applied to achieve faster convergence. The improvement could lead to acceleration up to a factor of n ğ‘› n , see Remark Â  6 . Furthermore, we extend FedExProx to client partial participation setting, showing the dependence of optimal extrapolation parameter on Ï„ ğœ \\tau which is the number of clients participating in the training and the benefits of a larger Ï„ ğœ \\tau . In particular, we show that compared to the single client setting, with complexity ğ’ª â€‹ ( L max Ïµ ) ğ’ª subscript ğ¿ italic-Ïµ \\mathcal{O}\\left(\\frac{L_{\\max}}{\\epsilon}\\right) , the full participation version enjoys a speed-up up to a factor of n ğ‘› n , see Remark Â  7 . â€¢ Our theory uncovers the relationship between the extrapolation parameter and the step size in typical gradient-type methods, leveraging the power of the Moreau envelope. We also recover RPM of Necoara etÂ al. ( 2019 ) as a special case in our analysis (see Remark Â  12 ), and show that the heuristic outlined in ( 4 ), is in fact a step size based on gradient diversity (HorvÃ¡th etÂ al., 2022 ; Yin etÂ al., 2018 ) for the Moreau envelopes of client functions. â€¢ Building on the insights from HorvÃ¡th etÂ al. ( 2022 ) , we propose two adaptive rules for determining the extrapolation parameter: based on gradient diversity ( FedExProx-GraDS ), and the stochastic Polyak step size ( FedExProx-StoPS ) (HorvÃ¡th etÂ al., 2022 ; Loizou etÂ al., 2021 ) . The proposed methods eliminate reliance on the unknown smoothness constant and exhibit â€œsemi-adaptivityâ€, meaning the algorithm converges with any local step size Î³ ğ›¾ \\gamma and by selecting a sufficiently large Î³ ğ›¾ \\gamma , we ensure that we lose at most a factor of 2 2 2 in iteration complexity. â€¢ We validate our theory with numerical experiments. Numerical evidence suggests that FedExProx achieves a 2 Ã— 2\\times or higher speed-up in terms of iteration complexity compared to FedProx and improved performance compared to FedExP . The framework and the plots are included in the Appendix. RPM refers to the randomized projection method of Necoara etÂ al. ( 2019 ) . Our method includes it as a special case, see Remark Â  12 Convexity: local objective f i subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– f_{i} is convex, which is the indicator function of the convex set ğ’³ i subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– \\mathcal{X}_{i} in RPM . The strong convexity pertains to f ğ‘“ f , and for RPM , it indicates that the linear regularity condition is satisfied. Smoothness: f i subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– f_{i} is L i subscript ğ¿ ğ‘– L_{i} -smooth. Our algorithm also applies in the non-smooth case; see Section Â  F.2 . Jhunjhunwala etÂ al. ( 2023 ) provides no convergence guarantee for client partial participation setting. The concept of â€œsemi-adaptivityâ€ is explained in Remark Â  9 . The Î± k , P subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğ‘ƒ \\alpha_{k,P} here is determined according to the theory of Jhunjhunwala etÂ al. ( 2023 ) . We have L Î³ â€‹ ( 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max ) â‰¤ L max subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ subscript ğ¿ L_{\\gamma}\\left(1+\\gamma L_{\\max}\\right)\\leq L_{\\max} , see Remark Â  6 . We leave out a factor of 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max 2 + Î³ â€‹ L max 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ 2 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ \\frac{1+\\gamma L_{\\max}}{2+\\gamma L_{\\max}} which is a constant between ( 1 2 , 1 ) 1 2 1 (\\frac{1}{2},1) . See Remark Â  11 for a lower bound of Î± k , S subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğ‘† \\alpha_{k,S} , using which we can rewrite the rate as L Î³ â€‹ ( 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max ) K subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ¾ \\frac{L_{\\gamma}\\left(1+\\gamma L_{\\max}\\right)}{K} . SGD (Robbins and Monro, 1951 ; Ghadimi and Lan, 2013 ; Gower etÂ al., 2019 ; Gorbunov etÂ al., 2020 ) stands as a cornerstone algorithm utilized across the fields of machine learning. In its simplest form, the algorithm is written as x k + 1 = x k âˆ’ Î· â‹… g â€‹ ( x k ) , subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ 1 subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ â‹… ğœ‚ ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ x_{k+1}=x_{k}-\\eta\\cdot g(x_{k}), where Î· > 0 ğœ‚ 0 \\eta>0 is a scalar step size, g â€‹ ( x k ) ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ g(x_{k}) represents a stochastic estimator of the true gradient âˆ‡ f â€‹ ( x k ) âˆ‡ ğ‘“ subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ \\nabla f(x_{k}) . We recover GD when g â€‹ ( x k ) = âˆ‡ f â€‹ ( x k ) ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ âˆ‡ ğ‘“ subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ g(x_{k})=\\nabla f(x_{k}) . The evolution of SGD has been marked by significant advancements since its introduction by Robbins and Monro ( 1951 ) , leading to various adaptations like stochastic batch gradient descent (Nemirovski etÂ al., 2009 ) and compressed gradient descent (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017 ; Khirirat etÂ al., 2018 ) . Gower etÂ al. ( 2019 ) presented a framework for analyzing SGD with arbitrary sampling strategies in the convex setting based on expected smoothness, which was later extended by Gorbunov etÂ al. ( 2020 ) to the case of local SGD . While many methods have been crafted to leverage the stochastic nature of g â€‹ ( x k ) ğ‘” subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ g(x_{k}) , substantial research efforts are also dedicated to finding a better stepsize. An illustration of this is the coordinate-wise adaptive step size Adagrad (Duchi etÂ al., 2011 ) . Another approach involves employing matrix step size, as demonstrated by Safaryan etÂ al. ( 2021 ); Li etÂ al. ( 2024 ) . Our analysis builds on the theory of SGD mainly adapted from Gower etÂ al. ( 2019 ) with additional consideration on the upper bound of the step size. PPM was first introduced by Rockafellar ( 1976 ) to address the problems of variational inequalities at its inception. Its transition to stochastic case, motivated by the need to efficiently solve large scale optimization problems, results in SPPM . It is often assumed that the proximity operator can be computed efficiently for the algorithm to be practical. Over the years, SPPM has been the subject of extensive research, as documented by Bertsekas ( 2011 ); Bianchi ( 2016 ); Patrascu and Necoara ( 2018 ) . Unlike traditional gradient-based methods, SPPM is more robust to inaccuracies in learning rate specifications, as demonstrated by Ryu and Boyd ( 2014 ) . Asi and Duchi ( 2019 ) studied APROX , which includes SPPM as the special case using the full proximal model; APROX was later extended into minibatch case by Asi etÂ al. ( 2020 ) . However, this extension was based on model averaging rather than iterate averaging. The convergence rate of SPPM has been analyzed in various contexts by Khaled and Jin ( 2022 ); Ryu and Boyd ( 2014 ); Yuan and Li ( 2022 ) , revealing that its performance does not surpass that of SGD in non-convex regimes. The projection method originated from efforts to solve systems of linear equations or linear inequalities (Kaczmarz, 1937 ; VonÂ Neumann, 1949 ; Motzkin and Schoenberg, 1954 ) . Subsequently, it was generalized to address the convex feasibility problem (Combettes, 1997b ) . Typically, the method involves projecting onto a set ğ’³ i subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– \\mathcal{X}_{i} , where i ğ‘– i is determined through sampling or other strategies. A particularly relevant method to our paper is the parallel projection method, in which individual projections onto the sets are performed in parallel, and their results are averaged in order to produce the next iterate. It is well-established experimentally that the parallel projection method can be accelerated through extrapolation, with numerous successful heuristics having been proposed to adaptively set the extrapolation parameter (Bauschke etÂ al., 2006 ; Pierra, 1984 ) . However, only recently a theory was proposed by Necoara etÂ al. ( 2019 ) to explain this phenomenon. Necoara etÂ al. ( 2019 ) introduced stochastic reformulations of the convex feasibility problem and revealed how the optimal extrapolation parameter depends on the smoothness of the setting and the size of the minibatch. A better result under a linear regularity condition, which is connected to strong convexity, was also obtained. However, the explanation provided by Necoara etÂ al. ( 2019 ) was not satisfactory, as it failed to clarify why adaptive rules based on gradient diversity are effective. The concept of the Moreau envelope, also known as Moreau-Yosida regularization, was first introduced by Moreau ( 1965 ) as a mathematical tool for handling non-smooth functions. A particularly relevant property of the Moreau envelope is that executing proximal minimization algorithms on the original objective is equivalent to applying gradient methods to its Moreau envelope (Ryu and Boyd, 2014 ) . Based on this observation, Davis and Drusvyatskiy ( 2019 ) conducted an analysis of several methods, including SPPM for weakly convex and Lipschitz functions. The properties of the Moreau envelope and its applications have been thoroughly investigated in many works including Jourani etÂ al. ( 2014 ); Planiden and Wang ( 2016 , 2019 ) . Beyond its role in proximal minimization algorithms, the Moreau envelope has been utilized in the contexts of personalized federated learning (TÂ Dinh etÂ al., 2020 ) and meta-learning (Mishchenko etÂ al., 2023 ) . One of the most crucial hyperparameters in training machine learning models with gradient-based methods is the step size. For GD and SGD , determining the step size often depends on the smoothness parameter, which is typically unknown, posing challenges in practical step size selection. There has been a growing interest in adaptive step sizes, leading to the development of numerous adaptive methods that enable real-time computation of the step size. Examples include Adagrad (Duchi etÂ al., 2011 ) , RMSProp ( Hinton etÂ al., ) , and ADAM (Kingma and Ba, 2015 ) . Recently, several studies have attempted to extend the Polyak step size beyond deterministic settings, leading to the development of the stochastic Polyak step size (RichtÃ¡rik and TakÃ¡c, 2020 ; HorvÃ¡th etÂ al., 2022 ; Loizou etÂ al., 2021 ; Orvieto etÂ al., 2022 ) . Gradient diversity, first introduced by Yin etÂ al. ( 2018 ) , was subsequently analyzed theoretically by HorvÃ¡th etÂ al. ( 2022 ) . 2 Preliminaries We now introduce the several definitions and assumptions that are used throughout the paper. The following assumptions are used in our analysis. We use the notation [ n ] delimited-[] ğ‘› [n] for the set { 1 , â€¦ , n } 1 â€¦ ğ‘› \\left\\{1,\\ldots,n\\right\\} . Note that 2 indicates that each f i subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– f_{i} and f ğ‘“ f are lower bounded. In this paper, we focus on cases where the interpolation regime holds. This assumption often holds in modern deep learning which are overparameterized where the number of parameters greatly exceeds the number of data points, as justified by Arora etÂ al. ( 2019 ); Montanari and Zhong ( 2022 ) . Our motivation for this assumption partly arises from the convex feasibility problem (Combettes, 1997a ; Necoara etÂ al., 2019 ) , wherein the intersection ğ’³ ğ’³ \\mathcal{X} is presumed nonempty. This is equivalent to assuming that the interpolation regime holds when f i subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– f_{i} is the indicator function of the nonempty closed convex set ğ’³ i subscript ğ’³ ğ‘– \\mathcal{X}_{i} . Further motivations derived from the proof for this assumption will be discussed later. It is important to note that the smoothness assumption here is not necessary to obtain a convergence result, see Section Â  F.2 for the detail. We introduce this assumption to highlight how the optimal extrapolation parameter depends on smoothness if it is present. The following strong convexity assumption is introduced that, if adopted, enables us to achieve better results. The function f ğ‘“ f is Î¼ ğœ‡ \\mu -strongly convex, Î¼ > 0 ğœ‡ 0 \\mu>0 . We first present our algorithm FedExProx as Algorithm Â  1 . In the subsequent sections, we first present the theory in the stochastic setting for FedExProx with a fixed extrapolation parameter in Section Â  3 . Then we proceed to adaptive versions of our algorithm which eliminates the dependence on the unknown smoothness constant in Section Â  4 . 3 Constant extrapolation In order to demonstrate the convergence result of our algorithm in the stochastic setting, we use Ï„ ğœ \\tau -nice sampling as the way of selecting clients for partial participation. This refers to that in each iteration, the server samples a set S k âŠ† { 1 , 2 , â€¦ , n } subscript ğ‘† ğ‘˜ 1 2 â€¦ ğ‘› S_{k}\\subseteq\\left\\{1,2,\\ldots,n\\right\\} uniformly at random from all subsets of size Ï„ ğœ \\tau . We want to emphasize that the sampling strategy here is merely an example, it is possible to use other client sampling strategies. Suppose 1 (Differentiability), 2 (Interpolation regime), 3 (Convexity) and 4 (Smoothness) hold. ( 2019 ) , to obtain function value suboptimality in terms of M Î³ â€‹ ( x ) superscript ğ‘€ ğ›¾ ğ‘¥ {M}^{\\gamma}\\left(x\\right) . Note that ( 8 ) unveils the connection between the step size of gradient type methods and extrapolation parameter in our case. Theorem Â  1 provides convergence guarantee for Algorithm Â  1 in the convex case. If in addition, we assume 5 (Strong convexity) holds, the rate can be improved and we obtain linear convergence. See Corollary Â  1 for the details. Theorem Â  1 indicates convergence for any 0 < Î³ < + âˆ 0 ğ›¾ 0<\\gamma<+\\infty . Indeed, as it is proved by Lemma Â  7 , we have C â€‹ ( Î³ , Ï„ , Î± Î³ , Ï„ ) = L Î³ , Ï„ â€‹ ( 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max ) â‰¤ L max ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ ğœ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ subscript ğ¿ C\\left(\\gamma,\\tau,\\alpha_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\right)=L_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\left(1+\\gamma L_{\\max}\\right)\\leq L_{\\max} holds for any 0 < Î³ < + âˆ 0 ğ›¾ 0<\\gamma<+\\infty . In cases where there exists at least one L i < L max subscript ğ¿ ğ‘– subscript ğ¿ L_{i}<L_{\\max} , we have C â€‹ ( Î³ , Ï„ , Î± Î³ , Ï„ ) < L max ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ¿ C\\left(\\gamma,\\tau,\\alpha_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\right)<L_{\\max} . This shows that the algorithm is successfully managing data heterogeneity One may question the necessity of the interpolation regime assumption. This assumption is crucial to our analysis. Besides allowing us to revisit the convex feasibility problem setting, it also guarantees that M Î³ â€‹ ( x ) superscript ğ‘€ ğ›¾ ğ‘¥ {M}^{\\gamma}\\left(x\\right) has the same set of minimizers as f â€‹ ( x ) ğ‘“ ğ‘¥ f(x) as illustrated by Lemma Â  8 . It also allows us to improve the upper bound on the step size by a factor of 2 2 2 in the SGD theory, which is demonstrated in Theorem Â  3 in the Appendix. From the reformulation presented in ( 8 ), we see the best extrapolation parameter is obtained when Î± k â€‹ Î³ subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğ›¾ \\alpha_{k}\\gamma is the best step size for SGD running on global objective M Î³ â€‹ ( x ) superscript ğ‘€ ğ›¾ ğ‘¥ {M}^{\\gamma}\\left(x\\right) . Since the best step size is affected by the smoothness and the minibatch size, so is the best extrapolation parameter. We can also compare our algorithm with FedProx in the convex overparameterized regime. Our algorithm includes FedProx as a special case when Î± = 1 ğ›¼ 1 \\alpha=1 . To recover its result, we simply plug in Î± = 1 ğ›¼ 1 \\alpha=1 , the resulting condition number is C â€‹ ( Î³ , Ï„ , 1 ) = 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max Î³ â€‹ ( 2 âˆ’ Î³ â€‹ L Î³ , Ï„ ) . ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğœ 1 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ 2 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ ğœ C(\\gamma,\\tau,1)=\\frac{1+\\gamma L_{\\max}}{\\gamma\\left(2-\\gamma L_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\right)}. Compared to FedProx , Algorithm Â  1 with the same Î³ > 0 ğ›¾ 0 \\gamma>0 demonstrates superior performance, with the acceleration factor being quantified by C â€‹ ( Î³ , Ï„ , 1 ) C â€‹ ( Î³ , Ï„ , Î± Î³ , Ï„ ) â‰¥ 2 + 1 Î³ â€‹ L max + Î³ â€‹ L max â‰¥ 4 . ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğœ 1 ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğœ 2 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ 4 \\frac{C(\\gamma,\\tau,1)}{C\\left(\\gamma,\\tau,\\alpha_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\right)}\\geq 2+\\frac{1}{\\gamma L_{\\max}}+\\gamma L_{\\max}\\geq 4. See Lemma Â  14 for the proof. This suggests that the approach of the server averaging all iterates following local computation is suboptimal. In the following paragraphs, we study some special cases, For the full participation case ( Ï„ = n ğœ ğ‘› \\tau=n ), using definition from Theorem Â  1 Î± Î³ , n = 1 Î³ â€‹ L Î³ > 1 , L Î³ , n = L Î³ , C â€‹ ( Î³ , n , Î± Î³ , n ) = L Î³ â€‹ ( 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max ) â‰¤ L max . formulae-sequence subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ 1 formulae-sequence subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ subscript ğ¿ \\alpha_{\\gamma,n}=\\frac{1}{\\gamma L_{\\gamma}}>1,\\quad L_{\\gamma,n}=L_{\\gamma},\\quad C\\left(\\gamma,n,\\alpha_{\\gamma,n}\\right)=L_{\\gamma}\\left(1+\\gamma L_{\\max}\\right)\\leq L_{\\max}. (9) In this case, we can compare our method with FedExP in the convex overparameterized setting. Assume the conditions in Theorem Â  1 hold, the worst case iteration complexity of FedExP is given by ğ’ª â€‹ ( L max Ïµ ) ğ’ª subscript ğ¿ italic-Ïµ \\mathcal{O}\\left(\\frac{L_{\\max}}{\\epsilon}\\right) , while for Algorithm Â  1 , it is ğ’ª â€‹ ( C â€‹ ( Î³ , n , Î± Î³ , n ) Ïµ ) ğ’ª ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› italic-Ïµ \\mathcal{O}\\left(\\frac{C\\left(\\gamma,n,\\alpha_{\\gamma,n}\\right)}{\\epsilon}\\right) . As suggested by Lemma Â  7 , Algorithm Â  1 has a better iteration complexity ( C â€‹ ( Î³ , n , Î± Î³ , n ) < L max ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ¿ C\\left(\\gamma,n,\\alpha_{\\gamma,n}\\right)<L_{\\max} ) whenever there exists L i â‰  L max subscript ğ¿ ğ‘– subscript ğ¿ L_{i}\\neq L_{\\max} for some i âˆˆ [ n ] ğ‘– delimited-[] ğ‘› i\\in[n] , and the acceleration could reach up to a factor of n ğ‘› n as suggested by Example Â  1 . In general, the speed-up in the worst case is quantified by L max 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max â‹… ( 1 n â€‹ âˆ‘ i = 1 n L i 1 + Î³ â€‹ L i ) âˆ’ 1 â‰¤ L max C â€‹ ( Î³ , n , Î± Î³ , n ) â‰¤ n â‹… L max 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max â‹… ( 1 n â€‹ âˆ‘ i = 1 n L i 1 + Î³ â€‹ L i ) âˆ’ 1 . â‹… subscript ğ¿ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ superscript 1 ğ‘› superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ¿ ğ‘– 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ‘– 1 subscript ğ¿ ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› â‹… ğ‘› subscript ğ¿ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ superscript 1 ğ‘› superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ¿ ğ‘– 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ‘– 1 \\frac{L_{\\max}}{1+\\gamma L_{\\max}}\\cdot\\left(\\frac{1}{n}\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\frac{L_{i}}{1+\\gamma L_{i}}\\right)^{-1}\\leq\\frac{L_{\\max}}{C\\left(\\gamma,n,\\alpha_{\\gamma,n}\\right)}\\leq n\\cdot\\frac{L_{\\max}}{1+\\gamma L_{\\max}}\\cdot\\left(\\frac{1}{n}\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\frac{L_{i}}{1+\\gamma L_{i}}\\right)^{-1}. For the single client case ( Ï„ = 1 ğœ 1 \\tau=1 ), using definition from Theorem Â  1 Î± Î³ , 1 = 1 + 1 Î³ â€‹ L max > 1 , L Î³ , 1 = L max 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max , C â€‹ ( Î³ , 1 , Î± Î³ , 1 ) = L max . formulae-sequence subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ 1 1 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ 1 formulae-sequence subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ 1 subscript ğ¿ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ ğ¶ ğ›¾ 1 subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ 1 subscript ğ¿ \\alpha_{\\gamma,1}=1+\\frac{1}{\\gamma L_{\\max}}>1,\\quad L_{\\gamma,1}=\\frac{L_{\\max}}{1+\\gamma L_{\\max}},\\quad C\\left(\\gamma,1,\\alpha_{\\gamma,1}\\right)=L_{\\max}. Compared with full and partial client participation, the following relations hold for any Ï„ âˆˆ [ n ] ğœ delimited-[] ğ‘› \\tau\\in[n] , C â€‹ ( Î³ , n , Î± Î³ , n ) â‰¤ C â€‹ ( Î³ , Ï„ , Î± Î³ , Ï„ ) â‰¤ C â€‹ ( Î³ , 1 , Î± Î³ , 1 ) and Î± Î³ , 1 â‰¤ Î± Î³ , Ï„ â‰¤ Î± Î³ , n , âˆ€ Ï„ âˆˆ [ n ] . formulae-sequence ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğœ ğ¶ ğ›¾ 1 subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ 1 and subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ 1 subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› for-all ğœ delimited-[] ğ‘› C\\left(\\gamma,n,\\alpha_{\\gamma,n}\\right)\\leq C\\left(\\gamma,\\tau,\\alpha_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\right)\\leq C\\left(\\gamma,1,\\alpha_{\\gamma,1}\\right)\\quad\\text{and}\\quad\\alpha_{\\gamma,1}\\leq\\alpha_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\leq\\alpha_{\\gamma,n},\\quad\\forall\\tau\\in[n]. Since the iteration complexity of FedExProx is given by ğ’ª â€‹ ( C â€‹ ( Î³ , Ï„ , Î± Î³ , Ï„ ) Ïµ ) ğ’ª ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğœ subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğœ italic-Ïµ \\mathcal{O}\\left(\\frac{C\\left(\\gamma,\\tau,\\alpha_{\\gamma,\\tau}\\right)}{\\epsilon}\\right) , the above inequalities tell us a larger client minibatch size Ï„ ğœ \\tau leads to a larger extrapolation and a better iteration complexity. Specifically, Lemma Â  7 suggests the improvement over the single client case could be as much as a factor of n ğ‘› n ( C â€‹ ( Î³ , n , Î± Î³ , n ) = 1 n â€‹ C â€‹ ( Î³ , 1 , Î± Î³ , 1 ) ğ¶ ğ›¾ ğ‘› subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ ğ‘› 1 ğ‘› ğ¶ ğ›¾ 1 subscript ğ›¼ ğ›¾ 1 C\\left(\\gamma,n,\\alpha_{\\gamma,n}\\right)=\\frac{1}{n}C\\left(\\gamma,1,\\alpha_{\\gamma,1}\\right) ) as suggested by Example Â  1 . 4 Adaptive extrapolation Observe that in Theorem Â  1 , in order to determine the optimal extrapolation, we require the knowledge of L Î³ , Ï„ subscript ğ¿ ğ›¾ ğœ L_{\\gamma,\\tau} , which is typically unknown. Although theoretically it suggests that simply averaging the iterates may result in suboptimal performance, in practice, this implication is less significant. To address this issue, we introduced two variants of FedExProx , based on gradient diversity and stochastic Polyak step size, given their relation to the extrapolation parameter in our cases. Suppose 1 (Differentiability), 2 (Interpolation regime), 3 (Convexity) and 4 (Smoothness) hold. (i) ( FedExProx-GraDS ): If we are using Î± k = Î± k , G subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğº \\alpha_{k}=\\alpha_{k,G} , where Î± k , G := 1 n â€‹ âˆ‘ i = 1 n â€– x k âˆ’ prox Î³ â€‹ f i â€‹ ( x k ) â€– 2 â€– 1 n â€‹ âˆ‘ i = 1 n ( x k âˆ’ prox Î³ â€‹ f i â€‹ ( x k ) ) â€– 2 â‰¥ 1 , assign subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğº 1 ğ‘› superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› superscript norm subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ subscript prox ğ›¾ subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ 2 superscript norm 1 ğ‘› superscript subscript ğ‘– 1 ğ‘› subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ subscript prox ğ›¾ subscript ğ‘“ ğ‘– subscript ğ‘¥ ğ‘˜ 2 1 \\alpha_{k,G}:=\\frac{\\frac{1}{n}\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\left\\|x_{k}-{\\rm prox}_{\\gamma f_{i}}\\left(x_{k}\\right)\\right\\|^{2}}{\\left\\|\\frac{1}{n}\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\left(x_{k}-{\\rm prox}_{\\gamma f_{i}}\\left(x_{k}\\right)\\right)\\right\\|^{2}}\\geq 1, (10) then the iterates of Algorithm Â  1 with Ï„ = n ğœ ğ‘› \\tau=n satisfy ğ”¼ â€‹ [ f â€‹ ( x Â¯ K ) ] âˆ’ inf f â‰¤ 1 + Î³ â€‹ L max 2 + Î³ â€‹ L max â‹… ( 1 Î³ + L max ) â‹… â€– x 0 âˆ’ x â‹† â€– 2 âˆ‘ k = 0 K âˆ’ 1 Î± k , G , ğ”¼ delimited-[] ğ‘“ subscript Â¯ ğ‘¥ ğ¾ infimum ğ‘“ â‹… 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ 2 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ 1 ğ›¾ subscript ğ¿ superscript norm subscript ğ‘¥ 0 subscript ğ‘¥ â‹† 2 superscript subscript ğ‘˜ 0 ğ¾ 1 subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğº {\\mathbb{E}}\\left[f(\\bar{x}_{K})\\right]-\\inf f\\leq\\frac{1+\\gamma L_{\\max}}{2+\\gamma L_{\\max}}\\cdot\\left(\\frac{1}{\\gamma}+L_{\\max}\\right)\\cdot\\frac{\\left\\|x_{0}-x_{\\star}\\right\\|^{2}}{\\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\\alpha_{k,G}}, where x Â¯ K subscript Â¯ ğ‘¥ ğ¾ \\bar{x}_{K} is chosen randomly from the first K ğ¾ K iterates { x 0 , x 1 , â€¦ , x K âˆ’ 1 } subscript ğ‘¥ 0 subscript ğ‘¥ 1 â€¦ subscript ğ‘¥ ğ¾ 1 \\{x_{0},x_{1},...,x_{K-1}\\} with probabilities p k = Î± k , G / âˆ‘ k = 0 K âˆ’ 1 Î± k , G subscript ğ‘ ğ‘˜ subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğº superscript subscript ğ‘˜ 0 ğ¾ 1 subscript ğ›¼ ğ‘˜ ğº p_{k}=\\nicefrac{{\\alpha_{k,G}}}{{\\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\\alpha_{k,G}}} .
